Sec. 7-51. - Adopted codes. 
(a)  Generally. As future new editions and/or amendments of the codes listed below are adopted by the Board of Community Affairs of the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, they shall become a part of or replacement for the adopted codes, rules and regulations or standards and shall become enforceable as prescribed without separate adoption by the governing authority. All new construction, installations, repairs or alterations shall be in conformance with the current edition of the following codes and referenced appendixes with Georgia amendments as currently adopted by the Board of Community Affairs of the Georgia Department of Community Affairs: 
(1)  International Building Code. 
(2)  International Residential Code and Appendix G. 
(3)  International Plumbing Code and Sections 703.6 of Appendix J in the Georgia Amendments. 
(4)  International Mechanical Code. 
(5)  International Fuel Gas Code. 
(6)  National Electrical Code. 
(7)  International Energy Conservation Code. 
(8)  International Fire Code. 
(b)  Referenced standards. Standards referenced in the above-stated codes shall be considered an integral part of the code without separate adoption. If specific portions of a standard are denoted by a code test, only those portions of the standard shall be enforced. Where code provisions conflict with a standard, the code provisions shall be govern. Permissive and advisory provisions in a standard shall not be construed as mandatory. 
(c)  Appendices. The appendices included in any code adopted pursuant to Division 3 of Article II of this chapter are not intended for enforcement unless specifically referenced in this chapter or specifically included in this Code. 
(d)  Referenced codes and standards. The adopted state codes adopted pursuant to this division shall be considered part of the requirements of this chapter to the prescribed extent of each such adoption. Where differences occur between the provisions of this chapter and referenced codes and standards, the provisions of this chapter shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, Pt. I, 8-10-04; Ord. No. 05-09, Pt. I, 7-26-05) 
Sec. 7-52. - Amendments to the International Building Code and International Residential Code. 
(a)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the International Building Code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  International Building Code. 
(A)  Chapter 1 is deleted in its entirely. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the International Residential Code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  International Residential Code. 
(A)  Chapter 1 is deleted in its entirety. 
(B)  Appendix G. of the International Residential Code is hereby adopted by the governing authority. 
(C)  Table 301.2(1) in Chapter 3 shall be completed by adding the following information to the blank spaces: 
(i)  Ground snow load (lbs. Per square foot) — 8. 
(ii)  Wind speed (fastest mile) — 90. 
(iii)  Seismic design category B. 
(iv)  Weathering — moderate. 
(v)  Frost line depth — Yes, 12" minimum. 
(vi)  Termite damage — Yes, very heavy. 
(vii)  Decay damage — Yes, moderate to severe. 
(viii)  Winter design temp. for heating facilities - 22°F. 
(ix)  Flood hazard May 7, 2001. 
(2)  Local supplemental ordinance requirements to the state adopted International Residential Code. 
(A)  A set of plans that include building, plumbing, mechanical, and electrical plans and the site plan as required in section 7-52(b)(2)(B) of this Chapter shall be maintained on the construction site at all times. 
(B)  A site plan or staking survey prepared and sealed by a registered engineer or land surveyor shall be submitted at the time of the residential footing or slab inspection and prior to the pouring of same. Survey shall show the setbacks from all property lines. Setbacks shall comply with all minimum zoning ordinance requirements and/or legally acquired variances. 
(C)  Upon request by the director, written certification shall be provided by the permittee or property owner that all concrete reinforcing and support stirrups comply with CSRI specifications. 
(D)  Upon request, batch tickets shall be provided to the director for each concrete pour. No more than one (1) gallon of water shall be added to each cubic yard of concrete mix during the concrete pour. All soil under a concrete slab shall be properly compacted and shall be covered with a minimum of six (6) mil polyethylene film to prevent the leaching of water from the concrete pour into the soil. The director may request the permittee, at the permittee's expense, to have any concrete slab and/or footing tested by an independent third party approved by the director. The director may take any and all appropriate action including, but not limited to, requiring removal of the concrete at the permittee or property owner's expense by a date certain if the director determines that: 
(i)  The concrete was poured in a manner contrary to this section or other law; 
(ii)  That the concrete was poured contrary to ACI specifications; or 
(iii)  That the slab or footings are defective as verified by the third party testing. 
(E)  Wood foundation walls are prohibited. An air infiltration barrier shall be installed between the foundation and all exterior walls. Foundation walls and piers of hollow masonry units shall be capped with a minimum of twenty-eight (28) gauge galvanized or comparable metal. Fifteen (15) pound felt shall be installed between nail down wooden floors and underlayment/subflooring. 
(F)  The skirt of the concrete apron for any driveway shall rise to no less that eight (8) inches above the flowline in the curb and the gutter and shall be eight (8) feet from the face of the curb at the flowline. 
(G)  All residential driveways, stops, patios, and walkways shall bear on properly compacted soil, foundation ledges or be doweled at slab. Maximum residential driveways slopes shall not exceed twenty (20) percent grade. At the entrance of a garage, the garage floor shall be elevated two (2) inches above the driveway or a drainage system approved by the director shall be installed at the entrance to the garage. Residential garages and carports shall contain not less than nineteen (19) feet six (6) inches of actual automobile parking depth. Upon completion of construction of any driveway or garage, the engineer of record shall provide written certification to the director that such driveway and/or garage complies with the requirements of this Code, including the requirements of this section. 
(H)  All residential basements and crawl spaces shall be damp proofed and positively drained regardless of water table and/or soil conditions. 
(I)  All residential floors shall be level and true. Concrete floors in basements or floors designed for human habitation shall not have pits, depressions or areas of unevenness that would prevent their use as finished sub-floors. The allowable slope tolerance for all floors shall not exceed one-fourth (¼) inch in thirty-two (32) inches. 
(J)  All residential bathroom wet floor areas shall be covered and protected by non-absorbent floor coverings. Dressing areas may transition to carpet. All shower and tub walls and ceilings shall be hung with moisture resistant dry wall that shall extend to the ceiling. 
(K)  All roofing shingles shall be installed and maintained during the entire construction per manufacturer's recommendations. Roofing shall be installed and sloped according to the manufacturer specifications using flashing and waterproof caulking to prevent leakage and moisture accumulation. 
(L)  Roof framing shall be tied securely to wall framing, using hurricane type connections. All exterior wall sheathing shall be made of seven-sixteenth ( 7/16 ) plywood or oriented strand board or other approved materials. Metal or self-sealing flashing shall be installed at least twelve (12) inches on either side of roof valleys. Drip edges shall be installed at all roofing edges. 
(M)  Residential gutters shall be continuously sloped for proper drainage and shall not contain depressions or swags to collect standing water. Drainage from gutter outlets shall be directed to a designed or natural drainage system that does not adversely affect adjacent property or buildings. 
(N)  The exterior wall facing a street of all residences shall have brick, stone, or real (lath and portland) stucco installed with the following exceptions: 
(i)  California styled all wood contemporary houses. 
(ii)  Pre-approved contract houses where the end user or architect specifies other material. 
(iii)  English Georgia or American Colonial/Craftsman all wood residential houses. 
(iv)  Any residential house that has an upper story cantilevered over the lower story, only the lower floor must be masonry veneered. 
(v)  Log homes. 
(vi)  State approved industrialized residential structures. 
(vii)  Designs approved by the county historic preservation commission. 
(O)  Seven-sixteenth ( 7/16 ) inch structural wood sheathing or other approved material shall be installed as underlayment on all residential exterior walls where vinyl siding is to be installed. All vinyl siding shall be a minimum material thickness of .044 inch and shall be installed by hand nailing using galvanized roofing nails. 
(P)  A weather resistant barrier shall be required as an underlay between all exterior siding or veneer. All exterior wood surfaces and fastener holes shall be sealed, treated and painted according to the manufacturer's specifications. All exterior wood and cementitious siding surfaces shall be sealed and painted according to the manufacturer's specifications. All exterior fasteners shall be coated and shall meet or exceed manufacturer specifications and standards for the specific application. 
(Q)  All windows and doors shall be installed with flashing to create a drain plain. All flashing shall be cut into adjoining surfaces where applicable. Light colored roofing and solar orientation principles shall be encouraged for use in all buildings. Flashing and caulking shall be installed at all exterior surfaces, roofs or appurtenances that are connected to another surface and such flashing and caulking shall extend to abutting structures. 
(R)  Crickets shall be installed behind all chimneys and shall extend the full width of the chimney chase. 
(S)  A three and one-half (3½) inch weep screed shall be installed at the bottom edge of the lath on all exterior hard coat stucco. The weep screen shall be mounted four (4) inches above finished grade and two (2) inches above impervious surfaces (walkways, patios and driveways). Metallic pipes penetrating stucco must be wrapped with materials to prevent corrosion of the pipe. Expansion joints shall be installed between floors. 
(T)  All topsoil shall be saved, protected and shall only be reused as topsoil but not used for fill. All disturbed areas on residential lots shall be totally sodded or landscaped with approved landscaped materials. All building material that are rendered unusable by natural elements (i.e. water, sun or soil) in the opinion of the director shall be immediately removed upon discovery and replaced with satisfactory material at the permittee or property owner's expense. 
(U)  Outside water-using or producing appliances such as an air conditioning cooling coil condensate shall be piped six (6) inches away from the dwelling unit foundation. 
(V)  Verification of subterranean termite control shall be submitted prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, Pt. I, 8-10-04; Ord. No. 05-09, Pt. I, 7-26-05) 
Sec. 7-53. - Amendments to the International Plumbing Code and International Mechanical Code. 
(a)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the International Plumbing Code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  International Plumbing Code. 
(A)  Chapter 1 is deleted in its entirety. 
(B)  Section 703.6 of Appendix J of the Georgia Amendments is hereby adopted by the governing authority. 
(2)  Local supplemental ordinance requirements to the state adopted plumbing code. 
(A)  Three (3) exterior frost proof hose bibbs separated as far as practical and installed in interior walls that interest exterior walls shall be installed on all residences. At least one (1) shall be installed in close proximity to the driveway. 
(B)  All exterior sewer drain clean outs shall be cut back to finished grade level on all residences. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the International Mechanical Code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  International Mechanical Code. 
(A)  Chapter 1 is deleted in its entirety. 
(2)  Local supplemental ordinance requirements to the adopted state mechanical code. 
(A)  Two (2) heating and air conditioning systems or one (1) system with zone controls and zoning dampers shall be installed in all multiple story residences. 
(B)  Residential heating and air conditioning systems (if air conditioning is installed) shall be sized to address all finished and unfinished interior areas (except garages). 
(C)  Drain pans with positive drains to the outside or kill switches shall be installed under all units with cooling coils when installed above a finished area. 
(D)  Fiberglass duct board shall not be allowed in residential structures. Runs of flexible duct shall not exceed fourteen (14) feet with the following installation standards and SMACNA Guidelines: 
(i)  Flexible duct shall be installed fully extended (not compressed). 
(ii)  Flexible duct shall be installed to avoid sharp bends, the radius at the centerline shall not be less than one (1) duct diameter. 
(iii)  Supports shall be provided at no greater separation than five (5) feet for horizontal runs and six (6) feet for vertical runs. 
(iv)  Supports shall be a minimum of four (4) inches wide sheet metal straps, shaped to fit the outside diameter of the duct per SMACNA Guidelines. 
(v)  Supports shall occur before and after each bend greater than forty-five (45) degrees. 
(vi)  Sheet metal collars to which ducts are connected shall be a minimum of two (2) inches. 
(vii)  Sheet metal sleeves not less than four (4) inches long shall be used for joining two (2) runs of duct. 
(viii)  All connections, joints and splices must be taped, and mastics when used for field installation shall meet UL Standard 181B and manufacturer's specifications. 
(ix)  Risers shall not exceed two (2) stories in height. 
(x)  Flexible ducts shall not be used within or through fire rated assemblies. 
(E)  Attic ventilation utilizing continuous ridge and soffit vents, cap vents or turbine vents shall be required. Powered ventilation may be utilized if natural draft ventilation cannot be achieved. 
(F)  Factory seams on low pressure systems do not have to be sealed when the minimum air leakage requirements of the Georgia State Energy Code for buildings have been met for the entire duct system. 
(G)  Pull down stairs or other permanent steps shall be installed to provide access to residential attics when mechanical systems are located in the same attic space. 
(H)  Ventilation fans shall be sized at one (1) CFM per square foot for all residential toilet, shower and tub areas. Separated toilet areas shall require a separate fan sized accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, Pt. I, 8-10-04; Ord. No. 05-09, Pt. I, 7-26-05) 
Sec. 7-54. - Amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code, the state adopted electrical code and the International Energy Conservation Code. 
(a)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the International Fuel Gas Code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  International Fuel Gas Code Code. 
(A)  Chapter 1 is deleted in its entirety. 
(B)  Section 703.6 of Appendix J of the Georgia Amendments is hereby adopted by the governing authority. 
(2)  Local supplemental ordinance requirements to the state adopted gas code. 
(A)  Gas lines shall be inspected and pressure tested at the rough-in inspection and final inspection. Gas lines shall not be connected to meter bars prior to the final inspection and final performance of the pressure test. Failure to comply is considered a dangerous and unsafe installation that may be subject the violator to penalties, enforcement actions, a citation for a violation of this chapter and any other remedy authorized by law. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the state adopted electrical code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  Local supplemental ordinance requirements to the state adopted gas code. 
(A)  Electrical fences consisting of an electrically charged conductor or other electrically charged devices shall be permitted to be used only for the confinement of farm animals. Only fence chargers of the intermittent current type listed by a nationally recognized independent testing laboratory shall be permitted to be used. Electrical fences shall not be used except by special permission after written application to the director. 
(B)  Buildings having two-hour fire rated vertical walls will be accepted as building separation and two (2) or more services shall be permitted. Horizontal separation shall not be construed as building separation. 
(C)  Unfinished rooms in residences that are framed and have mechanical duct installed and connected to the environmental system shall be wired with receptacles and switches according to NEC requirements. 
(D)  When a residential service change is installed, all receptacle outlets that are required under the current state adopted electrical code to be GFI outlets shall be modified to provide such protection, including bathrooms, kitchen counters, and outdoor receptacles. 
(E)  A reinspection permit and reinspection shall be required before power is restored to any residence or building where power has been disconnected for six (6) months or more. 
(F)  At least two hundred-amp service with a minimum of thirty (30) circuits is required for each dwelling unit that is two thousand (2,000) square feet or larger. 
(G)  All bedrooms and one additional room shall be wired for telephones, televisions and computers. The additional room may be split into two rooms without the requirement that both of the split rooms be wired for telephones, television and computers (example, phone in kitchen and TV and computer in family room). 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the state adopted electrical code adopted by reference in section 7-51 above is adopted with the following additions, deletions, modifications, or amendments: 
(1)  Amendments. 
(A)  The provisions in Chapter 7, Division 2, Codes Administration, of the Code, shall supplement Chapter 1 of the International Energy Conservation Code. When provisions of Chapter 7, Division 2, of the Code are in conflict with provisions of Chapter 1 of the International Energy Conservation Code, then the provisions of the International Energy Conservation Code shall take precedence and govern. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, Pt. I, 8-10-04; Ord. No. 05-09, Pt. I, 7-26-05) 
Secs. 7-55—7-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED[5] 

Footnotes:

Secs. 7-351—7-499. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING NUMBERING 

Sec. 7-500. - Assigning numbers; size; when to be erected; inspections not to be made unless numbers erected. 
Street numbers will be assigned for all buildings and structures. Numbers must be erected and displayed in front of the project on a board with permanent numbers not smaller than two (2) inches. Numbers must be in place at the beginning of the job before the footing inspection is made and be continuously displayed thereafter until the job is complete and all final inspections have been made. No inspection will be made where street numbers are not in place as required above. Contractors and others shall always refer to the street number when calling the public works-development department for an inspection request or information. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1003; Ord. No. 89-11, § 1(9-1001), 3-28-89) 
Sec. 7-501. - Designation of street numbers. 
Street numbers for dwelling units and places of business on all public streets and street numbers or building numbers for dwelling units and places of business within apartment projects and nonresidential developments located on private streets shall be assigned by the planning department in accordance with its administrative procedures. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1002; Ord. No. 89-11, § 1(9-1002), 3-28-89) 
Sec. 7-502. - Posting. 
(a)  Each one- and two-family dwelling unit constructed after July 1, 1986, shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of such dwelling unit in figures at least three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. 
(b)  Each one- and two-family dwelling unit constructed prior to July 1, 1986, shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of such dwelling unit in figures at least one (1) inch high on a contrasting background. 
(c)  Each multifamily (three (3) or more dwelling units) building shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the building, visible from the parking lot or street providing general public access, the address(es) or number(s) of the building in figures at least six (6) inches high on a contrasting background and each individual apartment/unit within the building shall be marked on or about its main entrance with the individual apartment/unit number and/or address in figures at least three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. In addition to the above, where a multifamily building has more than one (1) exterior entrance, each such entrance shall be marked, in figures at least (3) inches high on contrasting background, with the numbers and/or address of each and every individual apartment/unit to which access is provided through that common entrance. This shall be effective on all new and existing units July 1, 1986. 
(d)  Each place of business shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of the place of business in figures at least three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. This shall be effective on all new and existing places of business after July 1, 1986. 
(Code 1976, §§ 9-1001, § 9-1003; Ord. No. 89-11, § 1(9-1003), 3-28-89) 
ARTICLE V. - DEKALB DEVELOPMENT SERVICES FISCAL OVERSIGHT ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 7-503. - Creation and composition. 
(a)  The development services fiscal oversight advisory committee ("fiscal oversight committee") will be composed of stakeholders who are professionals in the development field and are familiar with DeKalb's permitting process. They will provide subject matter expertise to assist with recommending improvements. 
(b)  The fiscal oversight committee shall be composed of ten (10) members. 
(c)  Each of the following organizations shall submit one (1) recommended representative to the chief executive officer for appointment to the board of commissioners for approval. The chief executive officer may act on this recommendation or request an additional candidate for consideration. 
(1)  Greater Atlanta Homebuilders Association. 
(2)  DeKalb Chamber of Commerce. 
(3)  Atlanta Apartment Association. 
(4)  Georgia Chapter for the International Council of Shopping Centers. 
(5)  BOMA-Georgia. 
(6)  Atlanta Commercial Board of Realtors. 
(7)  American Council of Engineering Companies of Georgia. 
(8)  National Association of Industrial and Office Properties. 
(9)  Council for Quality Growth. 
(10)  Leadership DeKalb. 
Nominees should consist of members of the design community, such as architects and engineers, in addition to land use attorneys, developers, and other stakeholders. 
(d)  Each fiscal oversight committee member shall serve a two-year term and may be appointed to serve successive terms. 
( Ord. No. 15-01 , Pt. I, 1-13-15) 
Sec. 7-504. - Committee function. 
(a)  The fiscal oversight advisory committee is authorized to: 
(1)  Serve as an advisory committee to the administration and board of commissioners related to the fiscal management and policies of the DeKalb Development Services Division; 
(2)  Monitor development fund expenditures, revenues, and reserve levels, and provide input on fees and major purchases; 
(3)  Make recommendations regarding service levels, procedures, and staffing levels for development services; and 
(4)  Serve as ambassadors to DeKalb County in the Metropolitan Atlanta region. 
(b)  Meetings. The committee will elect a chair, vice-chair, and secretary to preside over the meetings and keep minutes. 
( Ord. No. 15-01 , Pt. I, 1-13-15) 
Sec. 7-505. - Staffing. 
The director of planning and sustainability shall provide necessary staffing to ensure effective operation of the fiscal oversight committee. 
( Ord. No. 15-01 , Pt. I, 1-13-15) 
Chapter 8 - CABLE TELEVISION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Business licenses and occupational taxes, § 15-26 et seq.; licensing of broadcast subscription television systems, § 15-35(3); permit, etc., required to install poles, pipes, etc., on public roads or alleys, § 23-6. 
State Law reference— General constitutional grant of home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ II; authority to regulate cable television systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-18-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Access channels means cable television channels available for use by citizens, government and educational institutions, including but not limited to the cablecast of meetings, hearings and programs of federal, state and local government and community organizations. 
Additional services means cable television service provided in addition to basic services on an optional basis, including, but not limited to, pay TV, home security, data transmission, facsimile reproduction, meter reading and home shopping. 
Applicant means any person submitting an application for a cable television franchise under this chapter and the terms and conditions set forth in any franchise ordinance entered into by the county and the applicant. 
Automated channels means cable television channels available for carrying time, weather, news, stock market quotations and community messages. 
Basic services means the cable television services available to all subscribers for a regular monthly service charge, excluding additional services for which a separate charge is made. 
Board of commissioners means the present governing authority of the county or any successor to the legislative powers of the present governing authority. 
Cable television system or CATV system means any nonbroadcast facility consisting of a set of transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control equipment, under common ownership and control, that distributes or is designed to distribute to subscribers the signals of one (1) or more television broadcast stations, but such term shall not include any such facility that serves or will serve only subscribers in one (1) or more multiple unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management. 
CATV means cable television. 
Channel means a frequency band capable of carrying audio or video signals to subscribers. 
Channel capacity means the number of activated channels to be offered to subscribers. 
Converter means an electronic tuning device which makes it possible for an ordinary television set to receive cable television service. 
County means the unincorporated areas of the county. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission or any successor agency having jurisdiction or regulatory power over cable television service. 
Franchise or CATV franchise means the privilege granted by the board of commissioners to a grantee under this chapter and a franchise ordinance to use the streets of the county to construct, equip and operate a CATV system in a designated area or areas in the county. 
Franchise area means the area of the county within which a CATV franchise is granted, whether such area is the entire county or a part of the county. 
Franchise ordinance means an ordinance adopted by the board of commissioners, consistent with this chapter, granting a CATV franchise to a particular grantee, and includes a confirming ordinance as defined in section 8-9. 
Grantee means the person to whom a CATV franchise is granted by the board of commissioners or any person to whom the interest of a grantee is assigned or transferred in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance. 
Gross revenue means all revenue derived directly or indirectly by a grantee from its CATV system within the county, including but not limited to charges for basic services and additional services, connection and reconnection, leased channels, converter rentals, studio rental, production equipment and personnel, and advertising revenues. Any taxes on cable television services imposed directly upon subscribers but collected by a grantee shall not be included in the gross revenue. 
Installation means the connection or reconnection of a CATV system feeder or trunk cable to a subscriber's terminal. 
Local origination means programs of local origin. 
Monitoring means observing a communications signal carried on a CATV system, or the absence of such a signal, by any person without regard to whether such observation is by visual or electronic means. Monitoring shall not include systemwide, nonindividually addressed sweeps of the CATV system for purposes of verifying the integrity of the system, controlling subscriber transmissions or billing for additional services. 
Pay TV means optional audio or video programs available to subscribers for a separate charge for each program or channel selected by the subscriber. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Rates means all rates, fees or charges paid by residential or nonresidential subscribers for basic services, the installation of the CATV system to subscriber terminals, and additional services to the extent that county regulation thereof would be consistent with applicable state and federal law. 
Streets means the surface of and the space above and below any public street, road, highway, freeway, lane, path, public way, or place, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive, sidewalk or other easement or right-of-way now or hereafter held by the county. 
Subscriber means a recipient of CATV service. 
Two-way channels means CATV channels which allow subscribers to transmit audio, video or other signals. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to provide the citizens of the county with a cable television and communications system equal to the highest state of the art and to promote variety in television and communication services by assuring a sufficient number of channels for entertainment, information and education. 
The terms of this chapter shall not apply if such an application would create an inequitable regulatory environment such that one cable or video provider operating within DeKalb County is subject to the terms of this chapter while another cable or video provider operating within DeKalb County is not. In all cases, a cable or video provider operating within DeKalb County shall be subject to the terms of its franchise agreement as well as all federal and state regulations and local police powers. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6001; Ord. No. 13-12 , Pt. I, 6-11-13) 
Sec. 8-3. - Funding of administrative expenses. 
All expenses incurred by the county with respect to administering this chapter and any franchise ordinance shall be funded out of the franchise fees collected pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6136) 
Sec. 8-4. - Grantee has no recourse against county enforcement; franchise acceptance is acceptance of terms, conditions. 
(a)  No grantee shall have recourse whatsoever against the county for any loss, cost or expenses or damage arising out of the provisions or requirements of the franchise or because of the enforcement thereof by the county. 
(b)  Each grantee expressly acknowledges that upon accepting a CATV franchise, it does so relying upon its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the county to grant the franchise. 
(c)  Each grantee, by acceptance of a CATV franchise, acknowledges that it has not been induced to enter into the franchise by any understanding or promise or other statement, whether verbal or written, by or on behalf of the county or by any other third person concerning any term or condition of the franchise not expressed in this chapter. 
(d)  Each grantee further acknowledges by acceptance of the CATV franchise that it has carefully read the terms and conditions thereof and is willing to and does accept all of the risks of the meaning of these terms and conditions. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6137) 
Sec. 8-5. - Failure of county to enforce franchise does not excuse compliance. 
No grantee shall be excused from complying with any of the terms and conditions of this chapter or a franchise ordinance by any failure of the county to insist upon or to seek compliance with any terms or conditions. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6138) 
Sec. 8-6. - Failure to perform act within prescribed time period. 
Whenever this chapter or a franchise ordinance shall set forth any time for any act to be performed by or on behalf of a grantee, this time shall be deemed of the essence and any failure of a grantee to perform within the time allotted shall always be sufficient grounds for the county to invoke the remedies available under the terms and conditions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6139) 
Sec. 8-7. - Grantee may not contest validity of franchise after acceptance. 
Each grantee agrees by the acceptance of a CATV franchise that it will not at any time set up against the county, in any claim or proceeding, any condition or term of the franchise as unreasonable, arbitrary or void or that the county had no power or authority to make such term or condition, but shall be required to accept the validity of the terms and conditions of the franchise in their entireties. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6140) 
Sec. 8-8. - Rights reserved by county. 
Without limitation upon the rights which the county might otherwise have, the county does hereby expressly reserve the following: 
(1)  To exercise its governmental powers to the full extent that these powers may be vested in or granted to the county. 
(2)  To determine through the board of commissioners any question of fact relating to the meaning, terms, obligations or other factors of the franchise. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6141) 
Sec. 8-9. - Existing CATV system. 
(a)  All the terms and conditions of this chapter shall apply to any CATV system now in operation in the county under a valid franchise, except as the board of commissioners may otherwise provide by resolution or ordinance, except that the existing CATV systems shall be given a reasonable time to bring their systems into compliance herewith. 
(b)  No existing CATV system may be expanded or extended into any part of the county beyond the limits of service lines existing and in operation on June 24, 1980, unless granted the privilege to do so by a franchise ordinance executed by the board of commissioners in accordance with all the terms and conditions of this chapter. 
(c)  The board of commissioners may confirm the validity of the CATV franchise for any existing CATV system by enactment of an appropriate ordinance (confirming ordinance) setting forth the amount of the letter of credit required under section 8-71, its franchise area (based upon the existing CATV system's claims to its franchise areas under previous ordinances and such other factors as the board of commissioners deems appropriate), the remaining term of its franchise and its present status with respect to compliance to the terms hereof. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the repeal (the 1976 CATV ordinance) by enactment of this chapter, and except to the extent as otherwise provided in a confirming ordinance, the validity and geographical extent of the franchise of any existing CATV system shall be determined by reference to the 1976 CATV ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6142) 
Sec. 8-10. - Citizens' advisory board. 
(a)  There is hereby created a CATV citizens' advisory board which shall consist of nine (9) members as follows: 
(1)  One (1) member appointed by the county board of education for a term not to exceed four (4) years. 
(2)  Each commissioner on the board of commissioners and the chief executive shall appoint one (1) member and the term of appointment for such member shall correspond to the term of office of the appointing commissioner or the chief executive. 
(b)  A chairperson shall be elected by the members of the CATV citizens' advisory board, and such chairperson shall serve in that capacity for a term of one (1) year. 
(c)  Any member of the advisory board missing two (2) consecutive meetings without just cause shall be relieved of duties and a replacement named. 
(d)  All members of the CATV citizens' advisory board shall serve without compensation and no member or any direct relative of any member shall have any interest, as a shareholder or the holder of a debt instrument, in any grantee. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the CATV citizens' advisory board to advise the board of commissioners regarding utilization and coordination of the CATV system's facilities, equipment and access channels which are made available for use by citizens, government and educational institutions under the franchise ordinances granted hereunder. 
(f)  Meetings of the CATV citizens' advisory board shall be held as needed at the call of the chairperson, but not less than once a year, with such financial and staff support as may be fixed by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6143; Ord. No. 88-01a, § 1,7-12-88) 
Sec. 8-11. - Impossibility of performance. 
Without limiting or restricting the applicability of the law relating to and governing the impossibility of performance of contracts, each grantee shall be relieved of and from undertakings, duties and responsibilities imposed upon such grantee by virtue of the terms of this chapter or any franchise ordinance where the performance of same has been prevented, curtailed or delayed by virtue of circumstances beyond the party's control, including but not limited to strikes, war (whether declared or not), acts of God, or changes of law (whether the result of legislative, executive, administrative or judicial action). Under such circumstances, the affected grantee shall not be deemed to have committed a breach of or be in default under the pertinent term or terms of this chapter or the franchise ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6144) 
Sec. 8-12. - Regulating authority of county. 
(a)  Each grantee shall construct, operate and maintain its CATV system subject to the supervision of all of the authorities of the county which have jurisdiction in these matters and in strict compliance with all laws, ordinances and department rules and regulations. 
(b)  The CATV system and all parts thereof shall be subject to the right of periodic inspection by the county. 
(c)  The chief executive may from time to time issue such reasonable rules and regulations concerning the construction, operation and maintenance of the CATV system as are consistent with the provisions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance, including, without limitation, rules and regulations for implementation of the complaint procedures set forth in section 8-169. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6081) 
Sec. 8-13. - Corrective action by county; recovery of costs. 
If a grantee should violate any of the terms of this chapter or the franchise ordinance, the chief executive shall give to the grantee written notice to correct such violation. If the grantee fails to correct such violation, make any repair, remove or relocate any part of its CATV system, or otherwise perform its obligations within thirty (30) days after the date of such written notice, or fails to justify the need for any further delay to the satisfaction of the chief executive, the county may cause the necessary work to be completed or services to be provided or other corrective action to be taken, and the grantee shall pay the county the costs thereof within ten (10) days of receipt of an itemized account of such costs. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6091) 
Sec. 8-14. - Assessment of liquidated damages. 
For the violation of any of the following provisions of this chapter, the board of commissioners may assess liquidated damages, as follows: 
(1)  For failure to provide CATV service in accordance with article III of this chapter, unless the board of commissioners specifically approves the delay by resolution, due to the occurrence of conditions beyond grantee's control, the grantee shall pay two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day for each day or part thereof that the delay continues. 
(2)  For failure to provide data, documents, reports and information as required by this chapter, the grantee shall pay fifty dollars ($50.00) per day that each violation occurs or continues. 
(3)  For failure to test, analyze and report on the performance of the system following a request pursuant to section 8-130, the grantee shall pay fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for each day or part thereof that such noncompliance continues. 
(4)  For failure to comply with the technical and operational standards set forth in article IV of this chapter following the county's resolution directing the grantee to make improvements pursuant to section 8-127, the grantee shall forfeit two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day or part thereof that the violation continues. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6092) 
Sec. 8-15. - Notice of public hearings. 
(a)  Notice of any public hearing shall be by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation published in the county, at least ten (10) days prior to the meeting, posting at the county courthouse and, if in connection with an existing CATV franchise, by all of the following methods: 
(1)  By announcement on at least two (2) primary channels of the grantee's CATV system between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m., for five (5) consecutive days immediately prior to the meeting. 
(2)  By a statement included in any billings delivered to subscribers before the date set for the public hearing. 
(b)  In this section "primary channels" means those channels which have the largest viewing audience as determined from time to time by recognized industry surveys. "Primary channels" does not include any channels on which a grantee is prohibited by law, contract or usage of trade from making public announcements, by reservation of time or otherwise. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6133) 
Secs. 8-16—8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FRANCHISES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-31. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to construct, operate or service a CATV system in the unincorporated area within the boundaries of the county unless granted a privilege to do so by a franchise ordinance as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  No CATV franchise shall be granted except by the board of commissioners by adoption of a franchise ordinance pursuant to this chapter. Each franchise ordinance shall designate a particular grantee and the franchise area to be served by the grantee. No person shall construct, operate or service a CATV system in the unincorporated area within the boundaries of the county unless granted a privilege to do so by a franchise ordinance. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-6011, 7-6127) 
Sec. 8-32. - Term. 
Each CATV franchise shall be for a term of fifteen (15) years and may be renewed only in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6012) 
Sec. 8-33. - Nonexclusiveness. 
Each CATV franchise shall be nonexclusive, and the county may grant more than one (1) CATV franchise for the same franchise area. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6013) 
Sec. 8-34. - Granting does not confer property rights. 
No grantee of a CATV franchise shall acquire any right of property in the streets or in other property owned by the county, and the county shall have no obligation to any grantee for maintenance of the streets or other property owned by the county. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6014) 
Sec. 8-35. - Annual franchise fee. 
(a)  Each grantee shall initially pay to the county an annual franchise fee equal to three (3) percent of its annual gross revenue; provided, however, such annual franchise fee may be increased up to a maximum of five (5) percent of a grantee's annual gross revenue at any time by resolution of the board of commissioners. Any increase in the annual franchise fee shall apply equally to all grantees and shall take effect immediately upon adoption of the enacting resolution unless otherwise specified by the board of commissioners. If the existing FCC limitation on franchise fees is raised or removed, then the annual franchise fee shall be as set by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  The annual franchise fee shall be paid to the county in monthly installments not later than fifteen (15) days after the end of each month on the basis of gross revenue received during the preceding month. At the end of its fiscal year and following the filing of the annual financial report required in section 8-168, each grantee shall remit any additional sums due as a result of such report. 
(c)  The annual franchise fee shall not be considered in the nature of a tax but shall be in addition to any and all taxes which are required to be paid by any law of the United States, the state or the county. 
(d)  The county shall have the right to inspect records of the grantee and the right to audit and to recompute any amounts determined to be due and payable by the grantee. Any such audit shall be performed within thirty-six (36) months following the close of each fiscal year of the grantee. Any additional amount due to the county as a result of the audit shall be paid within thirty (30) days following written notice to the grantee by the county, which notice shall include a copy of the audit report. 
(e)  If any franchise fee, cost or penalty is not paid on or before the due date to the county, a late charge and interest shall be assessed as specified in section 2-112. 
(f)  If a grantee serves areas outside the county and receives revenue for advertising both within and without the county, such advertising revenue shall be prorated to the county on a direct ratio between the number of subscribers within the county, and the total number of subscribers within and without the county, except as may be otherwise provided in a franchise ordinance. 
(g)  If a grantee is delinquent in any of its obligations under this section for a period of ninety (90) days, the grantee shall be considered in violation of this chapter and its CATV franchise may be terminated in accordance with the procedures set forth in this chapter, unless an extension is granted by the board of commissioners. Any such extension shall be limited to a period of sixty (60) days, and late charges and interest shall not be waived. 
(h)  No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the county may have for further or additional sums due and payable by the grantee or for the performance of any other obligation of the grantee. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6041; Ord. No. 88-32, 6-14-88) 
Sec. 8-36. - Subject to police powers. 
(a)  By accepting a CATV franchise, the grantee: 
(1)  Acknowledges that its privileges are subject to the police power of the county to adopt and enforce measures necessary to the safety, health and welfare of the public. 
(2)  Agrees to comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the county pursuant to such power. 
(b)  Any conflict between the provisions of a CATV franchise and any other present or future lawful exercise of the county's police powers shall be resolved in favor of the latter, except that any such exercise that is not of general application in the county or applies exclusively to the grantee or CATV systems which contain provisions inconsistent with the franchise shall prevail only if upon such exercise the county finds an emergency exists constituting a danger to health, safety, property or general welfare or such exercise is mandated by law. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6131) 
Sec. 8-37. - County use of grantee's facilities. 
The county shall have the right, during the term of a CATV franchise, to install and maintain free of charge upon the poles, towers or other equipment of the grantee any wire and fixtures that do not interfere with the operations of the CATV system. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6132) 
Secs. 8-38—8-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ISSUANCE PROCEDURES 

Sec. 8-51. - Outline of stages. 
The board of commissioners shall follow a five-stage process in granting each CATV franchise other than those granted pursuant to the terms of section 8-9. During the first stage, the board of commissioners shall solicit and receive applications for a CATV franchise. During the second stage, the board of commissioners shall designate one (1) or more applicants for detailed review of the application and negotiation of such matters as the type and extent of services to be offered. During the third stage, the board of commissioners and each designated applicant shall negotiate and draft a proposed franchise ordinance. The fourth stage shall consist of the grant of a CATV franchise by the board of commissioners by adoption of a franchise ordinance designating the proposed grantee and the franchise area to be served by the proposed grantee. The fifth stage shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Written acceptance of the franchise ordinance by the proposed grantee. 
(2)  A written franchise certificate issued by the chief executive to a proposed grantee evidencing a franchise granted under this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6021) 
Sec. 8-52. - Stage I, applications. 
(a)  The board of commissioners shall grant no CATV franchise without first soliciting applications by public notice in a form approved and adopted by resolution of the board of commissioners. Such public notice shall state the place and time during which application forms may be obtained, the place and deadline for filing of applications, a description of the proposed franchise area, and the amount of a nonrefundable application fee to be paid to the county concurrently with the filing of each application. The application forms shall be approved by the chief executive and shall require such information as the chief executive determines appropriate including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  If the applicant is not a corporation, its application shall contain the names and addresses of persons (including corporations) having a proprietary or equitable interest in its business operation and/or any proposed CATV franchise sought by the applicant. In this paragraph "equitable interest" includes all assignments for value, as well as all contingent assignments of any right or privilege under the proposed CATV franchise, and also includes any benefit, payment or emolument whatsoever resulting from the grant of a CATV franchise. 
(2)  If the applicant is a corporation not publicly held, as defined by the rules and regulations of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, the statement shall furnish, additionally, the names and addresses of its officers, directors and shareholders, together with the number of shares held by each shareholder. 
(3)  If the applicant is a corporation publicly held, as defined by the rules and regulations of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, the statement shall contain the states in which the applicant is incorporated and/or qualified to do business and the names and addresses of its officers and directors. 
(4)  The form of ownership of the facilities to be used in exercising the proposed CATV franchise. 
(5)  Any cable television system currently owned or operated by the applicant, its experience in operating and constructing such systems, any application pending for any other system, and the general financial resources of the applicant, as well as those specifically available for construction and operation of the proposed CATV system. 
(6)  Proposed services, including channel capacity, the number of channels and types of services to be included in basic services, the number of channels and types of services to be included in additional services, the number of two-way channels, the number of access channels and automated channels, facilities for local origination and a list of any additional service or facility to be made available to the county and other public, institutional and community organizations. 
(7)  A schedule of the subscriber rates for each of the proposed services. 
(8)  The equipment to be included in the CATV system, the general routes of the feeder or trunk cables, the number and location of signal amplifiers to be used in redistributing signals, the proposed franchise area and the service schedule for the proposed franchise area. 
(9)  The design and construction plans and standards to be used in constructing or renovating the CATV system and the proposed construction and service schedule. 
(b)  All applications shall be open to public inspection during reasonable business hours. 
(c)  Any material misrepresentation in an application or the omission of any material representation, which omission renders the included representations misleading, whether done negligently or intentionally, shall be grounds for rejection of the application or termination of any CATV franchise granted on the basis of such application. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6022) 
Sec. 8-53. - Stage II, selection of designated applicant. 
After the close of the filing period for applications for a CATV franchise, the board of commissioners shall hold an evening public hearing, review the applications submitted and, after considering the applicant's character, financial, technical and other qualifications and the adequacy and feasibility of its construction arrangements, by one (1) or more resolutions, designate one (1) or more applicants for participation in stage III of the selection process. Such designating resolution shall grant no rights, privileges or franchise of any kind, but shall be limited to designating one (1) or more applicants for stage III negotiations. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6023) 
Sec. 8-54. - Stage III, negotiation of proposed franchise ordinance. 
Upon designation pursuant to stage II of the procedures set out in this division, the board of commissioners and the designated applicant shall proceed to negotiate and draft the terms and conditions of a proposed franchise ordinance. At any time, the board of commissioners may do one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Terminate negotiations with the designated applicant and initiate or continue negotiations with any other designated applicant. 
(2)  By resolution designate another applicant from the original applicants for stage III negotiations. 
(3)  Return to stage I and reopen the time for the filing of new applications. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6024) 
Sec. 8-55. - Stage IV, grant of franchise. 
At any time after the date of the resolution designating a designated applicant pursuant to this division, the board of commissioners may grant a CATV franchise by adoption of a franchise ordinance naming a designated applicant as a proposed grantee. Such grant of a CATV franchise shall be conditioned upon the proposed grantee delivering the franchise acceptance documents described. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6025) 
Sec. 8-56. - Stage V, acceptance of franchise. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days after the date of the adoption of the franchise ordinance pursuant to stage IV of the procedures set out in this division, the proposed grantee shall deliver the following documents (the franchise acceptance documents) to the chief executive: 
(1)  A written acceptance of the CATV franchise in such form as is acceptable to the chief executive. 
(2)  A written indemnification agreement or its equivalent satisfying the requirements of section 8-73. 
(3)  The letter of credit described in section8-71. 
(4)  The insurance policies or certificates therefor described in section 8-72. 
(5)  A certified check written to the order of the county in such amount as shall be set by the board of commissioners as compensation to the county for costs incurred by the county in preparing and awarding the CATV franchise. 
(6)  A certified check written to the order of the county in such amount as shall be set by the board of commissioners to be held by the county and applied as a credit toward payment of the annual franchise fees by the grantee. 
(b)  Upon receiving the franchise acceptance documents, the chief executive shall have five (5) days to review same and determine whether or not they are in proper order and have been validly executed. If the franchise acceptance documents are deficient in any respect, the chief executive shall notify the proposed grantee of such deficiencies and the proposed grantee shall thereafter have five (5) days to remedy such deficiencies. 
(c)  If the proposed grantee fails to execute and deliver all the franchise acceptance documents within the thirty-day period provided in subsection (a) of this section or fails to remedy any deficiency in the franchise acceptance documents within the five-day period set forth in subsection (b) of this section: 
(1)  The franchise ordinance relating to the proposed grantee shall be null and void and of no further force and effect and the proposed grantee shall acquire no rights, privileges or franchise thereunder. 
(2)  The board of commissioners, by resolution, may designate another applicant from the original applicants for stage III negotiations, or may return to stage I and reopen the time for filing of new applications. 
(d)  If the franchise acceptance documents have been properly executed and delivered in accordance with this section, the chief executive shall issue a franchise certificate to the grantee evidencing the grantee's CATV franchise as of the date of such certificate. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6026) 
Secs. 8-57—8-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLATERAL DOCUMENTS 

Sec. 8-71. - Letter of credit. 
(a)  Concurrently with the delivery of the franchise acceptance documents, and as a part thereof, each grantee shall deliver to the county a letter or letters of credit in such amount as shall be set by the board of commissioners (the letter of credit). The letter of credit shall guarantee the faithful performance by the grantee of all provisions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance, including, without limitation, the grantee's obligations to construct, extend and improve its CATV system and the payment of civil penalties, claims, liens and taxes due the county. The letter of credit shall be issued in favor of the county by such financial institution and in such form and content as shall be required by the franchise ordinance and be approved by the chief executive. 
(b)  Each letter of credit shall be renewed or maintained continually during the entire term of the franchise ordinance or any renewal thereof at the dollar level set by the board of commissioners. 
(c)  The rights of the county under the letter of credit shall be in addition to all other rights of the county, whether granted by this chapter, the franchise ordinance or otherwise by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to the letter of credit shall affect any other right the county may have. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6031) 
Sec. 8-72. - Insurance policies. 
(a)  During the term of the CATV franchise, each grantee shall obtain, pay all premiums for and file with the chief executive executed duplicate copies and receipts evidencing the payment of premiums for the following: 
(1)  A general comprehensive public liability insurance policy indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the county, its officers, boards, commissions, agents or employees, from any and all claims by any person whatsoever on account of injury to or death of a person or persons occasioned, or alleged to have been occasioned, by the operations of a grantee, or alleged to have been so caused or occurred, with a minimum liability of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for personal injury or death of any one (1) person and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury or death of any two (2) or more persons in any one (1) occurrence. 
(2)  Property damage insurance indemnifying, defending and saving harmless the county, its officers, boards, commissions, agents and employees, from and against all claims by any person whatsoever for property damage occasioned, or alleged to have been occasioned, by the operation of grantee or alleged to have been so caused or occurred with a minimum liability for property damage of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) to any one (1) person and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage to two (2) or more persons in any one (1) occurrence. 
(3)  Builders' risk completed value form insuring the grantee's CATV system during construction thereof against fire, lightning and all other risks covered by the uniform standard extended covereage endorsement in its broadest form then in use in the state to the full insurable value of the CATV system, upon the repair or replacement basis. 
(4)  Hazard insurance insuring the grantee's CATV system during operation thereof against fire, lightning and all other risks covered by the uniform standard extending coverage endorsement in its broadest form then in use in the state to the full insurable value of the CATV system, upon the repair or replacement basis. 
(5)  Workers' compensation insurance at all times during the acquisition, renovation, construction or equipping of the grantee's CATV system. 
(b)  Such forms of insurance shall be kept in full force and effect by a grantee during the existence of and until after the removal of all poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other conductors and fixtures incident to the maintenance and operation of its CATV system as defined in its franchise ordinance. 
(c)  Each insurance policy shall: 
(1)  Be nonassessable and issued and maintained by companies authorized to do business in the state which are acceptable to the chief executive. 
(2)  Require thirty (30) days' written notice of any cancellation to both the county and the grantee herein. 
(3)  Be in such form as shall be acceptable to the chief executive. 
(d)  The insurance policies required under this section or duplicate copies thereof and insurance certificates with respect thereto shall be filed with the chief executive. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6032) 
Sec. 8-73. - Indemnification agreement. 
(a)  Each grantee shall execute an indemnification agreement prior to obtaining a franchise providing that it shall, at its sole cost and expense, fully indemnify, defend and hold harmless the county, its officers, boards, commissions, employees and agents against any and all claims, suits, actions, liability and judgments for damages to persons or property, in any way arising out of or through the acts or omissions of a grantee, its servants, agents or employees. 
(b)  These damages shall include but not be limited to damages arising out of copyright infringement and all other damages arising out of the installation, operation or maintenance of the CATV system, whether any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this chapter or the franchise ordinance. 
(c)  By acceptance of a CATV franchise or acceptance of the confirmation of an existing CATV franchise pursuant to section 8-9, each grantee expressly agrees that it will pay all expenses incurred by the county in defending itself with regard to all damages mentioned above. These expenses shall include, but not be limited to, all out-of-pocket expenses such as attorneys' fees and all other costs of litigation. 
(d)  No recovery by the county of any sum by reason of the letter of credit acquired in section 8-71 shall be any limitation upon the liability of the grantee to the county under the terms of this section, except that any sum so received by the county shall be deducted from any recovery which the county might have against the grantee under the terms of this section. 
(e)  By acceptance of a CATV franchise or acceptance of the confirmation of an existing franchise pursuant to section 8-9, each grantee expressly agrees that the county shall not be liable in excess of actual replacement costs for any damage occurring to the property of the grantee caused by employees of the county in the performance of their duties; nor shall the county be held liable for the interruption of services by the action of its employees in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6033) 
Secs. 8-74—8-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RENEWAL, TRANSFER, ETC. 

Sec. 8-86. - Renewal procedures. 
(a)  A CATV franchise may be renewed by the board of commissioners in accordance with applicable laws and the following procedures: 
(1)  Procedures for the renewal of any existing CATV franchise shall be governed by the provisions of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 (47 U.S.C. § 546). 
(2)  The board of commissioners shall hold at least one (1) public hearing on each application for renewal after giving public notice in the manner required by section 8-15. 
(3)  If the board of commissioners finds the grantee's performance satisfactory, an existing CATV franchise may be renewed for an additional period of ten (10) years by amendment of the franchise ordinance in accordance with this section on such terms and conditions as the board of commissioners determines to be appropriate. 
(b)  Renewal for additional periods of ten (10) years may be applied for by the grantee and granted by the county in accordance with procedures outlined in this section for the first renewal. 
(c)  If the board of commissioners fails to renew an existing CATV franchise before its expiration date, all rights, privileges and powers of the grantee in and to such CATV franchise shall terminate as of the expiration date, except as stated below: 
(1)  At all times from the expiration or revocation of a franchise and until a grantee transfers to the county or other succeeding operator of the CATV system all of its rights, title and interests to all assets, real and personal, related to its CATV system, the grantee shall have a duty to such successor as a trustee holding such assets for the benefit of such successor, and the grantee shall not sell any of the system assets nor shall the grantee make any physical, material or administrative operational changes that would tend to do any of the following: 
a.  Degrade the quality of service to the subscribers. 
b.  Decrease income. 
c.  Materially increase expenses without the expressed permission, in writing, of the county. 
The grantee shall at all times operate the CATV system in accordance with the terms of this chapter and the terms of the franchise as if the franchise had not expired or had not been revoked. 
(2)  In the event of expiration or revocation of a franchise, this section shall not be construed to give a grantee any vested or other franchise right, but the right of the grantee in such circumstances shall exist only on a day-to-day basis until the transfer is effected. 
(3)  For its management services during this interim period as a trustee, the grantee shall be entitled to receive as compensation the net profit generated during the period between the expiration or revocation of the franchise, as the case by be, and the transfer of the grantee's assets to the county or a successor, minus all operating expenses and franchise fees. 
(d)  This section does not limit the power of the county, upon expiration or revocation of a franchise, to require the grantee to cease all operations whatsoever and/or remove its facilities, or otherwise exercise any rights the county would otherwise have. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6111) 
Sec. 8-87. - Transfer of ownership or control. 
(a)  No CATV franchise and no rights or privileges thereunder shall be assigned or transferred, either in whole or in part, or leased, sublet or mortgaged in any manner, nor shall title thereto, either legal or equitable, or any right, interest or property therein, pass to or vest in any person without the prior written consent of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  No change, transfer or acquisition of control of a grantee shall occur without the prior written consent of the board of commissioners. A transfer of control will be deemed to occur upon the acquisition or accumulation by any person or an affiliated group of persons of fifty (50) percent or more of the voting stock of the grantee or of a percentage of the voting stock of the grantee which is larger than any other block of voting stock that is held by any one (1) person or an affiliated group of persons; provided, however, the transfer of a deceased stockholder's shares upon death, the transfer of a stockholder's shares to members of the stockholder's immediate family or to a trust benefiting members of the stockholder's immediate family, or the acquisition or accumulation of shares in an employee pension fund or such other similar fund shall not be deemed a change, transfer or acquisition of control. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything else contained in this section, no consent shall be required for any mortgage, transfer or assignment of part or all of a CATV system and the rights or privileges under a CATV franchise, or control of a grantee by trust deed, deed to secure debt, pledge or other hypothecation in favor of a bank, savings and loan association or other financial institution regularly engaged in the business of lending money, in order to secure an indebtedness incurred as part of a bona fide financing transaction entered into for the purpose of obtaining funds for the operation, acquisition, construction or improvement of a grantee's CATV system; provided, however, that any foreclosure upon such security shall be in accordance with section 8-88. 
(d)  Any consent or approval of the board of commissioners granted pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall not constitute a waiver or release of the rights of the county in and to the streets. All transfers approved by the board of commissioners pursuant to this section shall, by their terms, be expressly subordinate to the terms and conditions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance. 
(e)  In determining whether to approve a transfer pursuant to subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the board of commissioners may request that the proposed transferee supply such information, documents and proposals as it deems appropriate and may consider the entire purchase price or consideration to be paid by any proposed transferee, including the allocations of value which may affect subscriber rates, as well as the proposed transferee's character, experience and financial condition. The board of commissioners may condition its approval of any transfer so as to limit the portion of such purchase price which may be taken into consideration in setting subscriber rates. 
(f)  No transfer of ownership or control shall be valid without the successor in interest, if such successor in interest constitutes a separate legal entity, assuming in writing all the obligations and duties of the grantee under this chapter and the grantee's franchise ordinance and delivering to the chief executive the franchise acceptance documents within thirty (30) days after the date of such transfer in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 8-56. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6112) 
Sec. 8-88. - Foreclosure. 
Upon the foreclosure or other judicial sale of all or a part of a CATV system, or upon the termination of any lease covering all or a part of a CATV system, the grantee shall notify the chief executive of such event. A foreclosure or other judicial sale of all or a part of a CATV system, except a foreclosure or judicial sale to the holder of a mortgage, trust deed, deed to secure debt, pledge or other hypothecation acquired pursuant to subsection (c) of section 8-87, shall be treated as a change in control of the grantee, and the provisions of this chapter governing the consent of the county to such change in control shall apply. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6113) 
Sec. 8-89. - Termination due to substantial violation. 
(a)  The board of commissioners may terminate any CATV franchise and all rights and privileges of a grantee thereunder in the event of a substantial violation of the terms and conditions of either this chapter or the franchise ordinance. A substantial violation shall include, but shall not be limited to, any of the following: 
(1)  Willful failure, refusal or neglect to comply with the provisions of this chapter or a franchise ordinance or any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this chapter or a franchise ordinance. 
(2)  Any fraud or deceit, or attempted fraud or deceit, by a grantee in its conduct or relations under its CATV franchise with the county, subscribers or potential subscribers. 
(3)  Failure to meet the service schedule required under Article III of this chapter. 
(4)  Failure to restore service after ninety-six (96) consecutive hours of interrupted service, except when approved before such interruption or after by the chief executive. 
(5)  Material misrepresentation of facts or the omission of material facts necessary to make the facts stated not misleading in the application for a CATV franchise negotiation of a franchise ordinance or the delivery and execution of franchise acceptance documents. 
(6)  Failure to pay within sixty (60) days after final assessment of any civil penalty or liquidated damages. 
(b)  None of the foregoing shall constitute a substantial violation if such violation was without fault of the grantee or as a result of circumstances beyond the control of the grantee. A grantee shall not be excused by mere economic hardship or by misfeasance or malfeasance of its directors, officers, employees or agents. 
(c)  If a substantial violation occurs, the chief executive may initiate termination proceedings by making a written demand that the grantee correct such violation. If such violation continues for a period of thirty (30) days following such written demand, without the grantee's providing justification satisfactory to the chief executive for the delay, the chief executive may place the issue of termination before the board of commissioners for determination at a public hearing. 
(d)  If the board of commissioners determines that a substantial violation has occurred, the board of commissioners may, by resolution, do any of the following: 
(1)  Declare the CATV franchise of the grantee terminated. 
(2)  Assess civil penalties against the grantee. 
(3)  Extend the time for correction of the violation. 
(4)  Take such other action as the board of commissioners considers necessary and appropriate. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6093) 
Sec. 8-90. - Termination for appointment of receiver or trustee. 
The board of commissioners may terminate a CATV franchise one hundred twenty (120) days after the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over and conduct the business of the grantee, whether in receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy or other action or proceeding, unless within such time all of the following occur: 
(1)  Such receivership or trusteeship has been vacated. 
(2)  Such receiver or trustee has fully complied with all the provisions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance and remedied all defaults under either. 
(3)  Such receiver or trustee has executed and delivered a written agreement, approved by a court of proper jurisdiction, under which such receiver or trustee assumes and agrees to be bound by each and every provision of this chapter and the franchise ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6094) 
Sec. 8-91. - County purchase of system upon termination for cause. 
(a)  Upon termination for cause of a CATV franchise, the county, at its option, may purchase the CATV system from the grantee at a price not to exceed the adjusted fair market value. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall affect the right of eminent domain, and the option of the county to purchase a CATV system under the provisions of this chapter shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of, any other methods of acquisition of property interests available to the county. 
(c)  In this section "adjusted fair market value" means fair market value: 
(1)  Reduced by the costs and damages incurred by the county as a result of the breach of the grantee's obligations which resulted in the termination, if the purchase occurs upon a termination of a CATV franchise by the county; and 
(2)  With no value allocated to the grantee's franchise. 
(d)  Upon exercise of the option of the county to purchase the CATV system and the payment of the purchase price, the grantee shall: 
(1)  Transfer to the county possession and title to all facilities and property, real and personal, of the CATV system, free from any and all liens and encumbrances not agreed to be assumed by the county. 
(2)  Execute such warranty deeds or other instruments of conveyance to the county as shall be necessary for this purpose. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-6101—7-6103) 
Sec. 8-92. - Removal of CATV system upon expiration or termination of franchise. 
Upon the expiration or termination of a CATV franchise, the board of commissioners may require the grantee to immediately remove at the grantee's expense its CATV system from all streets and public property within the county. If the grantee fails to do so, the county may perform the work at the grantee's expense. Any property remaining in place in the streets or on public property one hundred twenty (120) days after expiration or termination shall be considered abandoned by the grantee, and ownership to such property shall, at the option of the board of commissioners, be considered transferred to the county. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6095) 
Secs. 8-93—8-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SERVICE SCHEDULE 

Sec. 8-106. - Initial service area. 
(a)  Each franchise ordinance shall designate the part of the franchise area (the initial service area) where CATV service shall be available to all subscribers within the times specified below after the date of the adoption of the franchise ordinance, as follows: 
(1)  Within one (1) year to at least twenty (20) percent of the dwelling units within the initial service area. 
(2)  Within two (2) years to at least fifty (50) percent of the dwelling units within the initial service area.
