(3)  Within three (3) years to all dwelling units within the initial service area. 
(b)  If the connection from a trunk or feeder cable to any dwelling unit would require more than a standard one-hundred-fifty-foot aerial drop line, or its underground equivalent, the grantee may charge the subscriber the actual cost of the connection for the distance exceeding one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6051) 
Sec. 8-107. - Extensions of service. 
(a)  Each grantee shall extend its CATV system and make CATV service available beyond the initial service area as follows: 
(1)  Within one (1) year after completion of construction within the initial service area, along streets or parts of streets reaching a minimum density of forty (40) dwelling units per street mile beginning at the boundary of the initial service area and any line extension beyond the initial service area; and otherwise in accordance with the provisions of the franchise ordinance concerning extensions of service. 
(2)  If the connection from a trunk or feeder cable to any dwelling unit within the areas provided for in paragraph (1) of this subsection would require more than a standard one-hundred-fifty-foot aerial drop line, or its underground equivalent, the grantee may charge the subscriber the actual cost of the connection for the distance exceeding one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
(3)  Service shall be provided to any person or persons outside the initial service area or the areas provided for in paragraph (1) of this subsection, if requested, upon payment to the grantee by such person or persons of all costs of extension, including, without limitation, costs of materials, labor and easements. 
(b)  Units under construction or for which building permits have been issued shall be considered a dwelling unit. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6052) 
Sec. 8-108. - Requests for service. 
Each grantee shall fill all requests for CATV service which are consistent with the foregoing schedule for service within thirty (30) days after the date of each request. A record of all service requests shall be kept for at least three (3) years and shall be available for public inspection at the local office of the grantee during regular office hours. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6053) 
Sec. 8-109. - Delay in meeting service schedule. 
Any substantial delay by a grantee in meeting the schedule for CATV service, unless specifically approved by the board of commissioners, shall be a violation of this chapter, subject to remedies provided in sections 8-13, 8-14, 8-89, 8-90 and 8-92. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6054) 
Secs. 8-110—8-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION OF CATV SYSTEM 

Sec. 8-126. - Compliance with laws, regulations and ordinances. 
Each grantee shall construct, install, operate and maintain its CATV system in a manner consistent with this chapter, the franchise ordinance and all laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements and FCC technical standards. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6061) 
Sec. 8-127. - Construction and technical standards. 
(a)  Each grantee shall comply with all county building and construction codes and such other construction and technical standards as shall be specified in the franchise ordinance. 
(b)  Each grantee shall maintain equipment capable of providing such signal quality and system reliability as shall be specified in the franchise ordinance. 
(c)  Each grantee shall incorporate into its CATV system a capacity to permit the county, in times of emergency, to override simultaneously the audio of all channels and shall designate a single channel for emergency broadcast of both audio and video signals. 
(d)  Each grantee shall construct and operate its CATV system so as not to interfere with emergency radio services and aeronautical navigation signals, and each grantee shall periodically check its CATV system for radio frequency (RF) leakage. 
(e)  Each grantee shall construct and operate its CATV system so as not to interfere with television reception of nonsubscribers or to interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner the operation of the various utilities serving county residents. 
(f)  Except for subscriber installation, no grantee shall make any excavation or attachment, erect any pole, install any wire and no construction of any kind shall be commenced without a permit issued by the county. Such permit may be issued after approval of layout maps and construction standards of the CATV system authorized by a franchise ordinance showing all equipment and routing or any utility poles to be used by the grantee, the location of all trunk and distribution lines and line amplifiers and the manner or method in which any such installation or construction shall be accomplished. 
(g)  If the board of commissioners by resolution declares that a grantee has failed to maintain the technical standards and quality of service required by this chapter or its franchise ordinance, the grantee shall immediately make such improvements as may be necessary. Failure to make such improvements within ninety (90) days after the date of such resolution or, if such improvements cannot be completed within such period, failure to institute timely action to do so within such period and diligently proceed to completion, shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6062) 
Sec. 8-128. - Use of streets. 
(a)  All transmissions and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by a grantee within the county shall be so located so as not to interfere with the proper use of the streets or the rights and reasonable convenience of owners of adjacent property. 
(b)  Except when necessary to service a subscriber, and then only when expressly permitted in writing by the county under such conditions as it shall prescribe, a grantee shall not erect any poles or facilities within the streets but shall use the existing poles and other equipment of utility companies under such an agreement as a grantee may negotiate with these companies. 
(c)  Whenever the county or the state shall require the relocation or reinstallation of any property of a grantee on the rights-of-way of the county, it shall be the obligation of a grantee, upon notice of such requirement, to immediately remove, relocate or reinstall such property as may be reasonably necessary to meet the requirements of the county or state. Such relocation, removal or reinstallation by a grantee shall be at the sole cost of a grantee. 
(d)  Whenever, in any place within the county, all the electric and telephone utilities are located underground, the grantee shall locate its property underground within such places. If the electric utilities or telephone utilites are located underground in any place within the county after a grantee has previously installed its property, the grantee shall, at the same time or immediately thereafter, also remove and relocate its property underground in such places. Facilities of a grantee placed underground at the property owner's request in any area where electric utilities or telephone utilities are aerial shall be installed with the additional expense paid by the property owner. 
(e)  Each grantee may trim trees overhanging the streets so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with its wires and cables. All trimming shall be done under the supervision and direction of the county and at the expense of the grantee. 
(f)  Each grantee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the county, replace and restore any disturbed street in as good a condition as before the work involving such disturbance was done; provided, that where a cut or disturbance is made in a section of sidewalk paving, rather than replacing only the area cut, a grantee shall replace the full width of the existing walk and length of the section or sections cut, a section being determined as that area marked by expansion joints or scoring. 
(g)  Each grantee shall maintain, repair and keep in good condition for a period of one (1) year following such disturbance all portions of a sidewalk or street disturbed by it or its agents, provided such maintenance and repairs shall be made necessary because of defective workmanship or materials supplied by the grantee. 
(h)  Each grantee shall, on the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by the county, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of such building. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of the wires shall be paid by the person making the request, and each grantee may require such payment in advance. Each grantee shall be given not less than forty-eight (48) hours' advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. Any disagreement between a grantee and a holder of a permit shall be resolved by the county. 
(i)  If at any time in case of fire or disaster in the county it shall become necessary, in the judgment of the person having charge of the disaster or fire or such person's designated agent, to cut or move any of the wire cables, amplifiers, appliances or other fixtures of a grantee, this may be done, and the repairs rendered necessary thereby shall be made by a grantee, at its own cost and expense, without charge against the county. 
(j)  The work of each grantee while in progress shall be properly executed at all times with suitable barricades, flags, lights, flares or other devices as are reasonably required to protect all members of the public having occasion to use the portion of the rights-of-way involved, or adjacent property. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6063) 
Sec. 8-129. - Operational standards. 
(a)  Each grantee shall put, keep and maintain all parts of its CATV system in good condition and repair during the term of the CATV franchise. 
(b)  Each grantee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum system use. Failure of a grantee to operate all or part of its CATV system for fifteen (15) consecutive days or a total of thirty (30) days in any calendar year without prior approval of the board of commissioners shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6064) 
Sec. 8-130. - Technical performance tests. 
(a)  The county may require a grantee to test and report on the technical performance of its CATV system; provided, however, that the county reserves the right to conduct its own tests upon reasonable notice to the grantee, and if noncompliance is found, the expense thereof shall be borne by the grantee. The county will endeavor to arrange its request for such special test so as to minimize hardship or inconvenience to a grantee or to subscribers. 
(b)  Each grantee shall provide the county with a written report on the results of its annual proof of performance tests conducted pursuant to FCC standards and requirements. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6065) 
Sec. 8-131. - Areawide interconnection of CATV systems. 
(a)  Each grantee, if ordered to do so by resolution of the board of commissioners, shall interconnect access channels of its CATV system with all other CATV systems in adjacent areas within or without the county. 
(b)  Upon receiving an order to interconnect, the grantee shall make a good faith effort to obtain agreement for the sharing of interconnection costs among all interconnecting companies. The board of commissioners may extend the time to interconnect or may rescind its order to interconnect upon finding that the grantee has made a good faith effort but has been unable to obtain a reasonable interconnection agreement or that the cost of the interconnection would cause an unreasonable increase in rates. 
(c)  Each grantee shall cooperate with any entity established for the purpose of regulating, financing or otherwise providing for the interconnection of CATV systems. 
(d)  The county may require a grantee to provide local origination equipment that is compatible with that used by other CATV systems. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6066) 
Sec. 8-132. - Regulation of basic service rates and charges of CATV systems. 
(a)  The county will follow the FCC Rate Regulations in its regulation of the basic service rates and charges of all cable television systems operating in the county, notwithstanding any different or inconsistent provisions in the franchise ordinance or existing franchise agreements to the contrary. 
(b)  In connection with such regulation, the county will ensure a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties. 
(c)  The board of commissioners, or its designated cable administrator, is authorized to execute on behalf of the county and file with the FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC Rate Regulations in order to enable the county to regulate basic service rates and charges. 
(Ord. No. 93-16, § 1, 11-23-93) 
Secs. 8-133—8-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 8-166. - Local office; resident manager. 
Each grantee shall maintain an office open to the public during reasonable business hours within the county and shall designate a resident manager to act for the grantee. The authority of the resident manager to act for the grantee with regard to operations of the CATV system shall be full and complete except as may be stated otherwise in the franchise ordinance. For matters in which the resident manager is not authorized to act for the grantee, a corporate officer having such authority shall be available to the county by phone. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6082) 
Sec. 8-167. - Rules and regulations of grantee. 
Each grantee may promulgate such rules and regulations governing the conduct of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to enable the grantee to exercise its CATV franchise to perform its obligations to assure uninterrupted service to its customers. All such rules and regulations shall be subject to and consistent with the provisions of this chapter and the franchise ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6083) 
Sec. 8-168. - Records and reports. 
(a)  Each grantee shall file annually the following records and reports with the county not later than three (3) months after the end of its fiscal year: 
(1)  The report to its stockholders, if any. 
(2)  An annual financial report in a form approved by the chief executive containing balance sheet, statement of income, statement of changes in retained earnings, statement of changes in ownership equity, notes to financial statements and supplementary schedules reconciled to the foregoing identifying revenues, expenses and income applicable to the operation of its CATV system. Such statements shall be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles applied on a consistent basis and shall be audited by an independent certified public accountant. 
(3)  A schedule of property used in its CATV system showing book value on the basis of original cost, less depreciation, with such supporting information as the chief executive may require. 
(4)  A facilities report setting forth the total physical miles of cable installed and the facilities currently in operation. 
(5)  A copy of proof of performance tests required under FCC regulations and standards. 
(6)  If a corporation is not publicly held, as defined by the rules and regulations of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, a list of all current shareholders and bondholders both of record or beneficial. If a corporation is publicly held, as so defined, a list of all shareholders who individually or as a concerted group hold five (5) percent or more of the voting stock of the corporation. 
(7)  A current list of all its officers and directors, including addresses and telephone numbers. 
(8)  A list of all pertinent agreements or contracts, including pole use agreements, entered into by the grantee during the fiscal year in the conduct of its business under a franchise granted hereunder; actual copies of contracts shall be supplied upon request. 
(9)  The names and both business and residential addresses and phone numbers of the franchisee's resident manager, engineer and/or consultant. 
(10)  Copies of all rules and regulations promulgated by the grantee during the fiscal year in the conduct of its business. 
(b)  The grantee shall file quarterly with the county, within forty-five (45) days of the end of each quarter, the following: 
(1)  Quarterly financial statements containing the same information required for annual financial statements under paragraph (a)(2) above which shall be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles applied on a consistent basis and shall be accompanied by a certificate of the grantee's chief financial officer attesting to their completeness and accuracy. 
(2)  A list of all complaints and CATV system down time received or experienced during the quarter. Such list shall also include complaint disposition and response time. For the purpose of this paragraph, certified copies of a complaint logbook reflecting all such incidents will suffice. The county shall have the right to review this complaint book at any time during the period. 
(c)  All such reports and records shall be available for inspection by the public at the county courthouse, and such other locations as the board of commissioners may designate. 
(d)  Each grantee shall simultaneously file with the chief executive a copy of each petition, application and communication transmitted by the grantee to, or received by the grantee from, any federal, state, local or other regulatory commissions or agencies having regulatory jurisdiction over any matters affecting cable television. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6084) 
Sec. 8-169. - Complaint procedure. 
(a)  Each grantee shall maintain a business office in the county for the purpose of receiving complaints regarding the lack of service (including that for which advance payments were made under section 8-128), the quality of service, equipment malfunctions and similar matters, which office shall be open during regular business hours. Each grantee shall provide reasonable means to accept complaint calls on a twenty-four-hour basis. All service complaints shall be investigated and acted upon promptly. A subscriber's account shall be adjusted for loss or lack of service on a per-day basis for loss or lack of service in excess of forty-eight (48) hours. Each grantee shall keep a complaint record indicating the nature of each complaint, the date received, the disposition of the complaint and the date. This record shall be made available for inspection by the county upon request. 
(b)  Each grantee shall furnish appropriate information to its subscribers concerning the procedures for making inquiries or complaints, including the address and local telephone number of both the grantee's representative and the county official to whom such inquiries or complaints are to be directed. 
(c)  A complaint may be submitted to the chief executive containing the name and address of the complainant, the name of the grantee against which the complaint is made and a statement of facts upon which the complaint is based. The chief executive shall forward a copy to the grantee or may take the question up by correspondence with the grantee. Within such time as is prescribed by the chief executive, the grantee shall satisfy the complaint or advise the chief executive of its refusal or inability to do so. If the grantee satisfied the complaint, it shall so notify the chief executive. The chief executive will forward a copy of the notice of satisfaction to the complainant. If the system refuses or is unable to satisfy the complaint, it shall so notify the chief executive, and the chief executive will forward a copy of this notice to the complainant, with a statement of the procedure to be followed to further prosecute the complaint. 
(d)  If a grantee satisfied any complaint brought to its attention by the chief executive, a statement must be filed with the chief executive setting forth when and how the complainant has been satisfied. When a complaint has not been satisfied, the complainant may file a complaint with the board of commissioners within six (6) months from the date of the notice from the chief executive. The board of commissioners may take such action with regard to the complaint as it considers appropriate. If no complaint is filed with the board of commissioners within the six-month period, the complainant will be deemed to have abandoned. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6085) 
Sec. 8-170. - Performance evaluation sessions. 
(a)  Cable communications is a new and rapidly changing field and many regulatory, technical, financial, marketing and legal changes are anticipated. To assure an advanced and modern system for the county, each grantee shall participate in performance evaluation sessions relating to service rate structures, free or discontinued service, application of new technologies, system performances, services provided, programming offered, customer complaints, subscriber privacy, two-way channels, proposed amendments to this chapter or the franchise ordinance, underground progress, and judicial and FCC rulings. Other subjects may be added by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  The county and each grantee shall hold a performance evaluation session within thirty (30) days after the third, sixth, ninth and twelfth anniversary dates of the adoption of the franchise ordinance. 
(c)  Special performance evaluation sessions may be held at any time set by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(d)  All performance evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and notice thereof shall be made in accordance with section 8-15. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6086) 
Sec. 8-171. - Employment program of grantee. 
A grantee shall not refuse to hire or employ, nor bar or discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any person in compensation or in terms, conditions or privileges of employment because of sex, race, creed, color, age, physical condition or national origin. Each grantee shall implement an affirmative action program of equal opportunity or employment for all qualified persons. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6121) 
Sec. 8-172. - Preferential or discriminatory rates. 
A grantee shall not as to rates, charges, service facilities, rules, regulations or any other respect make or grant any undue preference or advantage to any person or subject any person to any undue prejudice or disadvantage; provided, however, installation and service charges may be waived or modified during promotional campaigns of the grantee. Notwithstanding the foregoing, charges to commercial subscribers and bulk subscribers may be on a negotiated or other basis as established by grantee from time to time. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6122) 
Sec. 8-173. - Monitoring of subscribers. 
Monitoring of the viewing patterns, selections or return path transmissions of any subscriber shall be prohibited without the written permission of the subscriber. Such written permission shall be contained in a separate document. Such written permission may be revoked at any time by the subscriber. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the grantee may conduct systemwide or individually addressed sweeps for the purpose of verifying system integrity, controlling return-path transmission or billing for pay services. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6123) 
Sec. 8-174. - Subscriber lists. 
A grantee shall not sell or otherwise make available to any person a list of the names or addresses of subscribers or a list which identifies the viewing habits or return-path transmissions of subscribers without the written permission of each subscriber whose name or address is listed; provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall prohibit a grantee from making the names, addresses and/or telephone numbers of individual subscribers available to collection agencies and/or others authorized by the grantee to collect delinquent payments owed to the grantee. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6124) 
Sec. 8-175. - Editorial control. 
No editorial control may be exercised by a grantee with regard to any access channel. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6125) 
Sec. 8-176. - Sale or repair of television receivers. 
Neither the grantee nor any of its officers, agents, employees and consultants shall directly or indirectly engage in the sale or leasing of television receivers, radio receivers or television or radio parts except such parts and accessories required for cable connection, such as converters and connection plugs and accessories, individually or with any person anywhere in the county, whether for charge or not and whether in the performance of duties of the grantee or otherwise. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6126)

Chapter 11 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— General constitutional grant of home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ II; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 11-1. - Definition. 
In this chapter "emergency management" means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions, other than those functions for which military forces or other state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters of manmade or natural origin. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, protection from radiological and chemical hazards, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2021) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(1). 
Sec. 11-2. - Emergency management director. 
In agreement with the governing authority of this county, there is established the emergency management office within the department of fire and rescue services with the director of the department of fire and rescue services appointed as emergency management director. The emergency management director is charged with the following duties: 
(1)  To represent the governing officials of the county and cities and/or towns therein on matters pertaining to emergency management. 
(2)  To assist county and city officials in organizing county and city departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  To develop in conjunction with county departments and agencies the county emergency and disaster operations plan for the functions set forth in section 11-1. Such operations plan will be in consonance with the state emergency and disaster operations plan and shall be submitted to the governing authority of the county for approval. 
(4)  To maintain an emergency management office to carry out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency and disaster preparedness programs including the rendering of required reports to the state emergency management agency. 
(5)  To render reports such as financial, daily activity, etc., as required by governing officials in keeping with good business practices. 
(6)  To maintain with the authority of governing officials a facility to be used as the county emergency operation center. 
(7)  To coordinate the activities of the county emergency operating center staff during periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of the county governing authority. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2022; Ord. No. 11-02, Pt. I, §§ 2, 5, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 11-3. - Emergency management organization. 
The county emergency management organization shall be established around existing county departments and the emergency functions listed in section 11-1 are assigned as follows: 

 
The heads of the departments listed above are responsible for developing a departmental plan for the execution of their assigned emergency function and an annex to the county emergency and disaster operations plan. Such annexes will be submitted through the emergency management director to the board of commissioners in conjunction with their approval of the operations plan. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2023) 
State Law reference— Local emergency management organizations, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 
Sec. 11-4. - Emergency powers. 
In the event of manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the county, the chief executive officer of the county, jointly with the mayors of the cities of Avondale Estates, Chamblee, Clarkston, Decatur, Doraville, Lithonia, Pine Lake and Stone Mountain, or in their absence a legally appointed successor, may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources. 
(2)  To seize, take for temporary use or condemn any property for the protection of the public. 
(3)  To sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies. 
(4)  To establish, when necessary, local restrictions pertaining to curfew and the sale of liquor, gasoline and weapons. 
(5)  To perform and exercise such other functions and duties, and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the county. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2024) 
State Law reference— Local emergency management rules, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-28. 
Sec. 11-5. - Volunteers. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of the cities, towns and the county, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as county officers and employees. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2025) 
Sec. 11-6. - Violation of rules. 
No person shall violate any provision of any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2026) 
Sec. 11-7. - Prohibited pricing practices during state of emergency. 
(a)  It shall be an unlawful, unfair, and deceptive trade practice for any person, firm, or corporation doing business in any area in which a state of emergency, as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3 or in Dekalb County Code § 11-4, has been declared, for as long as such state of emergency exists, to sell or offer for sale at retail any goods or services necessary to preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or their property at a price higher than the price at which such goods were sold or offered for sale immediately prior to the declaration of a state of emergency; provided, however, that such price may be increased only in an amount which accurately reflects an increase in cost of the goods or services to the person selling the goods or services or an increase in the cost of transporting the goods or services into the area. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this Code section, a retailer or installer of lumber, plywood, and other lumber products may increase the price of such products as may be necessary to replenish his or her existing daily stock at current market rates, maintaining the same markup percentage he or she applied prior to the state of emergency. 
(Ord. No. 98-03, § 1, 4-14-98) 
Chapter 12 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, adopted April 12, 2005, deleted former Ch. 12 in its entirety and adopted new provisions as Ch. 12. Former Ch. 12, §§ 12-1, 12-26, 12-27, 12-29—12-39, 12-81—12-85, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1976, §§ 4-3001—4-3003, 4-3007—4-3015, 4-3019, 4-3071; Ord. No. 87-18, adopted Aug. 11, 1987; Ord. No. 89-18, § 1, adopted May 9, 1989; Ord. No. 90-19, § 1, adopted July 10, 1990; Ord. No. 91-22, adopted Sept. 24, 1991; Ord. No. 91-23, §§ 1—3, adopted Sept. 24, 1991; Ord. No. 93-12, adopted Aug. 24, 1993; Ord. No. 93-13, §§ 1—3, adopted Aug. 24, 1993; Ord. No. 95-01, adopted Jan. 24, 1995; Ord. No. 11-02, Pt. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; fire zones, § 17-150. 
State Law reference— Constitutional grant of power to provide for fire protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1); fire safety rules, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq.; false fire alarms, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-27. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Purpose. 
This chapter is an exercise of the police powers of DeKalb County, Georgia for the preservation and protection of the public health, peace, safety and welfare, and all the provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed for that purpose. The governing authority determines that there is also a need, in its adoption of the state minimum standard codes, to adopt certain amendments thereto. Local public safety conditions in the areas to which this chapter applies require amendments to the state minimum standard codes which are not less stringent than the state minimum standard code for the protection of life and property. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-2. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, certain terms and words are hereby defined. Where words are not herein defined, but are defined in section 1-2, those words shall have the meaning as defined therein. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them as directed above, except where the text clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Apartment building shall mean building(s) containing three (3) or more living units with independent cooking and bathroom facilities, whether designated as an apartment house, tenement, garden apartment, or by any other name. 
Battery backup shall mean any emergency power supply for power-assisted gates operated by electrical power. 
Breakaway security gate shall mean any gate designed to fall away under pressure. 
Case hardened metal shall mean a steel alloy formed by diffusing carbon and/or nitrogen into the outer layer of the steel at high temperature such that the metal cannot be cut with a saw, and will not shatter. 
Combustible shall mean any material that is capable of supporting ignition or the process of burning under heat exposure. 
Delayed response shall mean any postponement of an emergency vehicle gaining access through security barriers. 
Disposal shall mean the discharge, deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking, or placing of any hazardous substances or hazardous waste into or on any land or water so that such substances or waste may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any water, including groundwater. 
Dormitory shall mean building(s) or spaces in building(s) where group sleeping accommodations are provided for persons not members of the same family group in one (1) room or in a series of closely associated rooms under joint occupancy and single management, as in college dormitories, fraternity houses, military barracks; with or without meals, but without individual cooking facilities. 
Emergency shutoff button shall mean a device used to release hydraulic pressure on power-assisted gates operated by hydraulic power. 
Fire apparatus means any vehicle or equipment used by fire and rescue services. 
Fire marshal shall mean the individual designated by the chief of fire and rescue services department to direct the fire prevention bureau division of the department of fire and rescue services. 
Gamewell lock box shall mean a box, sometimes called an elevator lock box, which must be opened with a special key carried on fire response vehicles. 
Gravity gate shall mean a gate with no power assistance and which operates freely under manual manipulation. 
Hazardous explosive chemicals shall mean all picric acids, nitro-based chemicals, ethers, peroxides, oxidizers, and such other chemicals as may be determined by the fire marshal to be hazardous explosives. 
Hazardous substance shall mean a substance that satisfies any one (1) of the following requirements: 
(a)  A substance which, because of the toxic or hazardous properties which it exhibits, is determined by the Director of the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to represent a significant risk to the public health and safety as a result of foreseeable use, handling, accidental spill, exposure or contamination; or 
(b)  A substance that is known to present a significant risk of personal injury or illness as the foreseeable result of use, handling, accidental spills, exposure or contamination; or 
(c)  A substance or material that has been determined to pose an unreasonable risk to health, safety, and property. 
Hazardous waste shall mean any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal regulation in force and effective February 1, 1986, codified as 40 C.F.R. Part 261 — Identification and Listing of Hazardous Waste, as amended. 
Hazardous waste generation shall mean the act or process of producing hazardous waste. 
High-rise residential occupancy building shall mean hotels, dormitories, apartments, lodging or rooming houses, or board and care facilities over seventy-five (75) feet or twenty-three (23) meters in height measured from the lowest level of access available to the department of fire and rescue services to the floor of the highest occupied story. 
Hotel/motel shall mean a building(s) in which separate sleeping rooms are rented that provide sleeping accommodations for fifteen (15) persons or more on either a transient or permanent basis, with or without meals, whether designated as a hotel, inn, club, motel, or by any other name. 
Improper storage shall mean storage of chemicals past the expiration date on the label or chemicals stored in any area or container not designed for storage of the particular chemical. If there is no date listed for the expiration date, the expiration date shall be twelve (12) months past the date that the chemical was received by the person or entity storing the chemical. 
Lodging or rooming house shall mean a building(s) in which separate sleeping rooms are rented which provides sleeping accommodations for fifteen (15) or fewer persons on either a transient or permanent basis, with or without meals, but without separate cooking facilities for individual occupants. 
Pad lock shall mean any lock that is not constructed of case hardened metal. 
Power assisted gate shall mean any gate that is operated through a power source, whether electrical, hydraulic or pneumatic. 
Residential property shall mean building(s) containing three (3) or more living units with independent cooking and bathroom facilities, whether designated as apartment house, tenement, garden apartment, or by any other name. 
Substance shall mean any element, entity, compound, combination, or any mixture thereof, whether organic or inorganic. 
Toggle switch shall mean a device used to operate a power-assisted gate and override the power supply to the gate. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-3. - Scope. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply equally to both public and private property, and to all structures and their occupants, except as otherwise specified herein or by other applicable law. It shall be the duty of the employees of the department of fire and rescue services to enforce all applicable state laws regulations and all applicable provisions of the Code, in unincorporated DeKalb County, Georgia and in all municipalities with whom DeKalb County has a valid intergovernmental agreement for the provision of fire and rescue services. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 12-4. - Bureau of fire prevention established and duties of the fire marshal. 
(a)  The department of fire and rescue services shall administer and enforce those provisions of this chapter. Established within the department of fire and rescue services is a bureau of fire prevention and the bureau of fire prevention shall operate under the supervision of the fire marshal. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall possess the education, training and experience required by state law and the county for such position, and shall be responsible for the direct administration and enforcement of the provisions set forth in Article III of this Chapter. The director of fire and rescue services may designate additional personnel as from time to time shall be necessary to serve under the direction of the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-5. - Bureau of fire prevention; duties of the officers. 
(a)  The duties of the fire prevention bureau shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  The prevention of fires; 
(2)  Oversight of the storage and use of combustible, flammable or explosive material; 
(3)  The enforcement of laws requiring the installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm systems, and fire extinguishing equipment; 
(4)  The enforcement of laws governing the maintenance and regulation of fire escapes; 
(5)  The enforcement of laws governing the means and adequacy of exits from factories, schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theatres, amphitheaters and all other places in which persons work, live or congregate, from time to time for any purpose; and 
(6)  The creation and maintenance of fire cause and loss records. 
(b)  The bureau of fire prevention shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire by which property has been destroyed or damaged and, as far as possible, shall determine whether the fire is the result of an intentional act provided that such fire occurred in unincorporated DeKalb County, Georgia or within the boundaries of those municipalities with whom DeKalb County has a valid intergovernmental agreement for the provision of fire and rescue services. Such investigations shall begin upon notice of such a fire, and if an intentional act is suspected, the fire marshal shall take charge immediately of physical evidence and cause a complete investigation to be initiated to include referral of a completed investigation to the proper prosecuting authority for prosecution of the responsible parties. 
(c)  The bureau of fire prevention shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as are set forth in other applicable sections of this Code, and as may be conferred or imposed upon the bureau or the fire marshal from time to time by federal, state or local law. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-6. - Construction plans approval. 
It shall be unlawful to construct, erect or alter any building, except one- and two-family dwellings, without construction documents approved by the fire marshal for fire department accessibility, fire hydrant requirements, fire code requirements, occupancy load, aboveground and underground flammable and combustible liquids tank installations and fire protection systems, including but not limited to sprinklers. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-7. - Records and annual reports. 
(a)  The fire marshal shall compile and keep a record of all fires. Said record shall include but is not limited to information regarding injuries, deaths, rescues of persons, and statistics as to the damage caused by such fires and whether and to what extent losses were covered by insurance. Said record shall be compiled from the reports made by inspectors and investigators of the department of fire and rescue services. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall compile an annual report of the activities of the bureau of fire prevention and shall transmit this report to the fire chief for the department of fire and rescue services. 
(c)  The DeKalb County fire and rescue services officer in whose jurisdiction any fire occurs shall report each fire in writing to the fire marshal within two (2) days after the occurrence. The report shall be in a form prescribed by the fire marshal and shall contain a statement of all facts relating to the cause, origin, and circumstances of such a fire; the extent of the damage thereof, and the insurance upon the property and such other information as may be required, including the occurrence of any injury, death or rescue of persons. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-8. - Permits. 
(a)  Before permits for blasting, fireworks, industrial process and any other permit issued may be issued as required by this chapter, the fire marshal shall inspect and approve the receptacles, processes, vehicles, buildings, or storage places to be used for any such purposes. 
(b)  The board of commissioners shall establish the fees for any initial inspection and follow-up inspection as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Secs. 12-9—12-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS AND ADOPTED CODES 

Sec. 12-20. - Adoption of state fire safety rules. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 25-2-1 et seq. and as may hereinafter be amended, there is hereby adopted as if fully set forth herein the state fire safety rules now and as may hereafter be promulgated by the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner. In the event the fire marshal determines that the provisions of the state fire safety rules conflict with the provisions of the International Fire Code adopted in section 12-21, then the most restrictive provision as determined by the fire marshal shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-21. - Adoption of International Fire Code. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 8-2-20 and section 8-2-25 and as may hereinafter be amended, there is hereby adopted as if fully set forth herein the International Fire Code, including Chapter 1, Administration. As allowed in O.C.G.A. section 8-2-25, the provisions of the International Fire Code are modified and amended in sections 12-22 through section 12-26. In the event the fire marshal determines that the provisions of the International Fire Code conflict with the provisions of the state fire safety rules adopted in section 12-20, then the most restrictive provision as determined by the fire marshal shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-22. - Amendments to the International Fire Code. 
(a)  The International Fire Code is hereby amended by omitting section 108, Board of Appeals of Chapter 1, Administration and section 108 shall not be adopted by the County. 
(b)  The International Fire Code is hereby amended by adopting Appendix C-Fire Hydrant Locations and Distribution and Appendix D-Fire Apparatus Access Roads. Section D107 of Appendix D-Fire Apparatus Access Roads shall not be adopted by the County. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-23. - Spread of fire. 
(a)  All combustible landscaping materials shall be placed at least thirty-six (36) inches away from the edge of any building having an external skin of either combustible sheathing or combustible siding. Aluminum siding, vinyl siding, non-treated wood siding and similar materials shall be considered combustible for the purpose of this section. This section shall not be interpreted to prohibit the planting of shrubs, trees and other live plant materials closer than thirty-six (36) inches away from the edge of any other building. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite a fire of any type within four (4) feet of a combustible building, including ignition under combustible overhangs and balconies. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-24. - Automatic fire extinguisher system required. 
(a)  All new multifamily dwellings properties shall be fully sprinkled in accordance with the latest adopted edition of the National Fire Protection Association publications 13 ("NFPA-13") or 13R ("NFPA 13R"). 
(b)  All existing high-rise residential occupancy buildings shall have an approved sprinkler system installed in accordance with NFPA-13. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-25. - Security gate/barrier installation requirements other than one-and two-family dwellings. 
(a)  Installation requirements for all gates. 
(1)  All gates shall have a minimum width of fourteen (14) feet to allow for fire apparatus access. 
(2)  All gates shall have signage indicating gate direction of travel. 
(3)  All objects on a gate that may obstruct the path of emergency vehicles must be covered with reflective paint, tape or lights sufficient to guide vehicles around the obstruction. 
(4)  The owner of the property shall ensure that all hydraulic gates are disabled and left in the open position when the temperature is expected to drop below twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(5)  If a gate is located on a turn, the turn must have a thirty (30) foot clear inside radius and a fifty (50) foot clear outside radius. 
(6)  Gate installers shall provide information on the operational features of the gate to the fire services bureau prior to the installation of any security gate. 
(7)  The fire marshal prior to installation of any security gate must approve its operational features. 
(8)  When gates are opened for emergency access, they shall remain open until reactivated. 
(9)  Construction plans or blueprints shall be submitted to the development department for approval by the fire marshal prior to an owner or applicant beginning work on the installation of a gate. 
(b)  Installation requirement for power-assisted gates. 
(1)  Gamewell: Property owners shall ensure that Gamewell lock boxes or any means of security approved by the fire marshal shall conform to the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Power assisted gates shall contain a toggle switch to manually operate the gate and override the power. 
(3)  The property owner shall install in gates operated by electrical means a battery backup to keep the toggle switch operational. 
(4)  The property owner shall also ensure that the power-assisted gate is equipped to operate manually. 
(5)  Property owners shall ensure that hydraulic gates have an emergency button or knob to release pressure. The button or knob shall be located at the hydraulic arm, and one (1) shutoff is required for each arm. If the emergency shutoff is used, the gate must be capable of being secured to prevent it from swinging back to the closed position. 
(c)  Installation requirements for gravity gate locking devices. 
(1)  Pad locks may be used to secure a gate only if the pad lock is not constructed of case hardened metals. 
(2)  Gates shall be installed to allow fire apparatus to access the property and not impede the flow of traffic. This includes a sufficient distance to allow gates to open if swinging in the direction of the fire apparatus. 
(d)  Installation requirements for chain and pole security barriers. 
(1)  Property owners must seek approval from the fire marshal prior to the use of chain and pole barriers. 
(2)  Chains and pole barriers must not be constructed of case hardened metal. 
(e)  Installation requirements for break away security gates. 
(1)  When the security gate arm is raised, the property owner must ensure that the arm remains raised until reset for normal operation. 
(2)  The mechanism for overriding the gate shall be accessible to the employees of the fire services bureau. 
(3)  When in use, the gate arm should be open to an angle greater than ninety (90) degrees to the terrain of the driveway. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-26. - Requirements for disabling security gates and other barriers at residential properties other than one-or two-family dwellings. 
(a)  No fire apparatus shall proceed through any gate while on an emergency run without first disabling the gate. Disabling the gate shall also be required in the event the gate is already in the open position. Disabling a gate will be conducted in compliance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Power assisted gates shall be disabled by opening the Gamewell lock box, and/or activating the push button or the toggle switch. 
(2)  On gates equipped with chains and padlocks, the fire and rescue services officers may cut the chain near the padlock or cut the padlocks, whichever procedure will provide the best access to the emergency. After opening the padlock or chain, the chain may be used to secure the gate(s) to prevent the gate from closing. 
(3)  No gate shall be restored to normal operation until the last fire apparatus or vehicle leaves the property. The last fire unit shall be responsible for seeing that the gate is taken out of emergency mode or configuration. 
(4)  DeKalb County, its officials and employees shall not be responsible for delayed response resulting from gaining access through security barriers. 
(5)  The owner of the property at issue shall be responsible for any damage to emergency apparatus caused by security gates or barriers. 
(6)  Employees of the department of fire and rescue services shall not be responsible for securing any gate after completing their fire fighting or fire prevention duties. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-27. - False fire alarm. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to transmit or cause to be transmitted in any manner to fire and rescue services a false report of a fire, knowing at the time there is no factual basis for believing that such a fire exists. Such a violation shall be prosecuted under applicable state law as a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED 

Secs. 12-28—12-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - INSPECTIONS, VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 12-40. - Responsibility for violations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this chapter, to permit or maintain such a violation, to refuse to obey any provision thereof, or to fail or refuse to comply with any such provision or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-41. - Inspections. 
(a)  Employees of the bureau of fire prevention shall be authorized to conduct inspections on public and private property, from time to time for the purpose of enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. If the owner or tenant of such property does not give consent for such inspection(s), the employees of the bureau of fire prevention shall obtain a warrant from the DeKalb County Recorder's Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction for such inspection in accordance with the warrant requirements of state law. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall inspect or cause to be inspected all premises, except one- and two-family dwellings, on a periodic basis, and shall issue such directives as may be necessary for the enforcement of the laws and ordinances governing the same and for safeguarding of life and property. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-42. - Removal of fire hazards, compliance. 
(a)  Whenever any employee of the department of fire and rescue services shall find in any building, or upon any premises or other place, combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulation of rubbish or unnecessary accumulation of waste paper, boxes, shaving, or any highly flammable materials, and which is so situated as to endanger property or persons; or shall find obstructions to or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows, that interfere with the operations of the fire and rescue services or egress of persons in case of a fire or other hazardous condition, the fire marshal shall issue an order, that the same are to be removed or remedied, and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or buildings. 
(b)  The service of orders for the correction of violations of this chapter shall be made upon the owner, occupant, or other person responsible for the conditions, either by delivering the same to or leaving it with any person in charge of the premises, or in case no such person is found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door to the entrance of said premises. Whenever it is necessary to serve such an order upon the owner of said premises, such order shall be served either by delivering to and leaving with the person a copy of said order, or, if such owner is absent from the jurisdiction of the officer making the order, by sending such copy by certified or registered mail to the owner's last known address as indicated in the records of the tax commissioner. 
(c)  Any person served with an order who shall fail to comply with such order within a reasonable period after the service of the said order shall be subject to the issuance of a citation as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-43. - Service of citation. 
The service of any citation under this Code may be made by personal service upon the occupant of the premises to whom it is directed. A copy of the citation shall be filed with the recorders court of DeKalb County. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Sec. 12-44. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter as hereby adopted or fails to comply therewith or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement or specifications of plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, shall for each and every such violation or noncompliance, be guilty of an ordinance violation. Upon conviction of the violation in a court of competent jurisdiction, the individual shall be subject to fine and/or imprisonment in accordance with section 1-10 of this Code. 
(b)  The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation nor shall the violation be permitted to continue. Any person convicted of a violation under this chapter shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time, and when not otherwise specified, the application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Secs. 12-45—12-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HAZARDOUS EXPLOSIVE CHEMICALS 

Sec. 12-60. - Improper storage prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or institution to keep hazardous explosive chemicals, which are used or stored for which the expiration date has passed. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, Pt. I, 4-12-05) 
Chapter 13 - HEALTH REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Editor's note— Although this chapter has been adopted by ordinance of the board of commissioners, it is derived from rules adopted by the board of health. Insofar as possible, the language has been kept identical to that adopted by the board of health. 
Cross reference— Animals, Ch. 5; nuisances, Ch. 18; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 5; local laws relating to health and human services, App. B, § 401 et seq. 
State Law reference— General constitutional grant of home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ II; general authority of county board of health to adopt rules, O.C.G.A. §§ 31-3-4(a)(4), 31-3-6; adoption procedures for rules, O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1.

No. 96-02R, adopted June 11, 1996 prohibited the self-inspection of sewer lines by plumbers and utility contractors in DeKalb County as specified in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d). The user's attention is directed to Act No. 1046, § 3 which provides for the exemption from said self-inspection procedures. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Board means the DeKalb County Board of Health, State of Georgia. 
Department means the department of human resources, State of Georgia. 
Director means the chief executive officer of the board as defined in O.C.G.A. §§ 31-3-11 and 31-3-12, or the designee of the director. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1001; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-2. - Selection of members of board of health. 
The following procedure shall be used for selecting a member of the board of health whenever the legal situs of the largest municipality of the county lies within an adjoining county: 
(1)  The county governing authority shall select the chief executive officer, by whatever name designated, of the governing authority of any municipality lying wholly or partially within the county to fill the position on the board authorized by O.C.G.A. § 31-3-2(a)(7) or any other provisions. 
(2)  The chief executive officer so selected may designate another member of the respective municipal governing authority, whose term of office is the same as that of the chief executive officer, to serve in the place of the chief executive officer. 
(3)  The chief executive officer so selected or the chief executive officer's designee shall serve for a term of office as a member of the board concurrent with the term of office as a member of the municipal governing authority. 
(4)  A vacancy in the position on the board which is held by the chief executive officer or the chief executive officer's designee shall be filled for the unexpired term by the county governing authority. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1007; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Sec. 13-3. - Inspection warrants; investigations. 
(a)  The director may obtain an inspection warrant in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 31, ch. 5, art. 2 [§ 31-5-20 et seq.] when there is probable cause to believe that a condition or circumstance exists which legally justifies such an inspection to enforce the regulations of the board, the rules of the department, or a provision of law. 
(b)  The director shall promptly investigate every bona fide complaint coming within the jurisdiction of the board. The director may exercise discretion to refuse to investigate anonymous complaints. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1002; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Sec. 13-4. - Permits and approvals generally. 
All applications for permits or written approval required by any regulation of the board of health shall be made on forms prescribed and furnished by the director and shall be signed by the applicant, who shall be the person responsible for conformance to the conditions of the permits or approval applied for. Applications shall contain such information and be accompanied by such plans as the director shall deem necessary. A permit issued to a particular person or for a designated place or purpose shall not be valid for use by any other person or for any other place or purpose than that designated therein. These permits or written approvals may contain general and specific conditions and every person who has obtained a permit or written approval containing these conditions shall conform to the conditions prescribed in the permit or written approval and to the provisions of all applicable regulations. Every permit shall expire as stated on the permit and may be renewed, suspended for cause or revoked by the director after due notice and hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1003; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Sec. 13-5. - Approval of business licenses and building permits. 
(a)  Whenever any regulation of the board requires approval by the director of plans for any building or structure, no municipality or agency of the county shall issue or renew a building permit for this building or structure without first having obtained a written statement from the director that the plans therefor comply with all the applicable regulations of the board. 
(b)  Whenever any regulation of the board of health requires sanitary inspection and approval of any establishment by the director, no municipality or agency of the county shall issue or renew any business license for this establishment without first having obtained a written statement from the director that the establishment complies with all applicable regulations of the board. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to restrict or abrogate the authority of any municipality or agency of the county to adopt and enforce additional regulations or ordinances or to enforce existing regulations or ordinances relative to the regulation, control, issuance, renewal or revocation of any business license or building permit, except as herein provided. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the director to keep the appropriate municipal and county officials informed as to the provisions of this section and the regulations of the board to which it applies. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1004; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Sec. 13-6. - Conflicting provisions. 
Whenever there is in effect any rule or provision of any regulation or ordinance of any governmental agency or municipality which is more strict than the corresponding provision of a regulation of the board, the director shall hold in abeyance the enforcement of this provision of the board regulation and cooperate with the agency or municipality in enforcing the stricter rule or provision of its regulations or ordinances. If the director elects to hold in abeyance the enforcement of this provision and, after a reasonable time, the agency or municipality shall have failed to enforce its rule or the provision of its regulations or ordinances, the director shall proceed with the enforcement of the corresponding provision of the board regulation. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1005; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Sec. 13-7. - Violations. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and subject to the provisions of section 1-10 and O.C.G.A. § 31-5-8. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1006; Ord. No. 88-04a, 8-9-88) 
Secs. 13-8—13-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 13-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hearing means a right of the DeKalb County Board of Health, its officials and employees, and persons and parties affected by an action or an intended action of the director or the board to present testimony, documentary evidence and argument as to why such action should or should not be taken. A hearing may be conducted by either the director, the director's designee or the board. 
Notice of hearing means a written statement of the intended action to be taken and, where applicable, the substance of a specific charge alleging violation of any rule or statute to be considered at hearing. 
In the case of a specific charge to be considered, where a license, permit, certificate or similar right is proposed to be denied, suspended or revoked, notice shall be given in person or by registered or certified mail to all interested parties; provided, however, in proceedings where the number of interested parties is so numerous as to make individual notice impracticable, notice shall be given by publication or by such other means reasonably calculated to afford actual notice as may be prescribed by the person conducting such hearing. 
All notices shall state the time and place of hearing, the nature thereof and the matters of fact and law asserted and must be given at least five (5) days before the day set for hearing, unless the director or board determines that an imminent threat to the public health exists which requires shorter notice. 
The affected parties may waive in writing the required notice of hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1021) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-27. - Denial, revocation or suspension of license, permit, etc.; written notice required. 
No license, permit, certificate or similar right shall be denied, revoked, or suspended without first giving the affected party prior written notice of the intended action and affording the party an opportunity for hearing under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1022) 
State Law reference— Revocation or suspension of licenses, permits, etc., O.C.G.A. § 31-5-2. 
Sec. 13-28. - Effectiveness of rules and regulations. 
All rules and regulations of the board shall be adopted, amended, revised or repealed after notice and hearing according to law. No rule or regulation shall become effective as law until thirty (30) days after its adoption, except in cases of emergencies constituting an imminent threat to the public, in which event such rule or regulation shall become effective upon adoption; but, in all cases, the board shall, as a part thereof, state the conditions found by it to justify such immediate effectiveness. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1023) 
State Law reference— Adoption procedures for rules,O.C.G.A. § 31-51-1; distribution of copies of rules, O.C.G.A. § 31-5-6. 
Sec. 13-29. - Hearing—Procedure. 
(a)  Where a hearing is required or afforded, all interested parties at such hearing shall have, upon request, compulsory process and shall have the right to adduce evidence and conduct cross-examination of all adverse witnesses. Any member of the board, its authorized officials or agents, or any attorney-at-law may administer oaths to all witnesses. No witness shall be abused while under examination or required to incriminate himself or herself. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 31-5-2(c). 
(b)  The board is authorized and empowered to direct the director or the director's appointee to conduct hearings, issue compulsory process, administer oaths and submit findings and recommendations to the board. In such cases, the report of findings and recommendation shall be available to all interested parties, and such parties shall be entitled to file written exception thereto prior to final decision by the board. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 31-5-2(d). 
(c)  Unless precluded by law, informal disposition may be made by the director and the affected party by stipulation, agreed settlement, consent order or default. 
(d)  The order of proof in the conduct of a hearing should be somewhat flexible. Generally, the following procedure will be followed: 
(1)  The representative of the board who has asserted the claim or makes the charge shall be heard first. 
(2)  After the conclusion of the board representative's presentation, the opposing party should then be heard. 
(3)  The giving of testimony by each respective party and the party's witnesses is subject to appropriate cross-examination. 
(4)  The person conducting the hearing may call or recall a witness where necessary to provide a full and fair hearing of the matter. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1024) 
Sec. 13-30. - Same—Record. 
A record of the hearing shall be kept and shall include, but not be limited to, all pleadings, motions and rulings; a summary of the oral testimony and all other evidence received or considered, except that a party shall have the right, at the party's own expense, to have the proceedings recorded and transcribed and may enter that transcript as part of the official hearing record; all staff data submitted to the director or board in connection with consideration of the case; all rulings, orders, reports and opinions entered by the director or board. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1025) 
Sec. 13-31. - Same—Confidential documents. 
(a)  Documents, reports, data and other information obtained by the director or the board from any person, firm, corporation, municipality, county or other public authority and/or political subdivision, where such matters relate to secret processes, formulae, or where such matters were obtained on a confidential basis, shall be classified as confidential and privileged documents. 
(b)  Upon receipt of any confidential and privileged document, the director or board shall label it "Confidential and Privileged—Not For Release." Such document shall be maintained in a secure file and shall be subject to disclosure only in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 31-5-5 and any other applicable statute. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1026) 
State Law reference— Confidentiality, etc., of documents, O.C.G.A. § 31-5-5. 
Sec. 13-32. - Same—Final decision. 
The board shall make a final decision in writing stating the underlying facts supporting the decision and shall send by certified mail a copy of such final decision to the parties affected thereby. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1027) 
Sec. 13-33. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any party adversely affected by a final decision of the board may have a review thereof by appeal to the department under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 31-5-3 within thirty (30) days after rendition of the final order. 
(b)  The petition of the aggrieved party shall state the reasons why and in what respect such party is aggrieved and the grounds to be relied upon as a basis for the relief demanded. 
(c)  The appealing party shall file the original petition with the department and furnish the board with a copy thereof. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the appeal by the board, the board shall forward a complete transcript of the hearing record to the department. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1028) 
Sec. 13-34. - Variances. 
(a)  The regulations of the board shall be administered by the director who shall have the authority to grant a variance from the requirements of a regulation of the board as follows: 
(1)  Where it is demonstrated to the satisfaction of the director that strict compliance with a standard would result in practical difficulty to or undue hardship upon a property owner due to special conditions or causes; 
(2)  Where the public or private interest in the granting of the variance is found by the director to clearly outweigh the interest of the application of uniform rules; and 
(3)  Where such alternative measures are provided which, in the opinion of the director, will provide adequate public health and safety protection. 
(b)  In granting a variance, the director may attach thereto any conditions which may be deemed advisable so that the purpose of this chapter will be served and the public health, safety and welfare secured. 
(c)  Where a variance requested under the provisions of this section is denied, the property owner may be afforded a hearing as provided in section 13-27. 
(Ord. No. 89-10, § 1(12-1029), 3-28-89) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 89-10, adopted Mar. 28, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 1(12-1029) as § 13-34 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 13-35—13-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisances generally, Ch. 18; property maintenance, § 7-351 et seq. 
State Law reference— Health nuisances prohibited, O.C.-G.A. § 41-1-6; abatement of health nuisances by injunctive relief, O.C.G.A. § 31-5-9 et seq. 

Sec. 13-51. - Enumerated. 
The following conditions are specifically declared to be nuisances: 
(1)  Toilets, plumbing, sewers, septic-tank systems, garbage containers or any other sanitary facilities in bad repair. 
(2)  Conditions conducive to the breeding or attraction of rodents, flies, fleas, ticks, mosquitoes or any other disease-carrying insects. 
(3)  Manmade or mechanically induced noxious air contaminants. 
(4)  Trash, garbage, refuse or any foul, decaying or putrescent material kept, used, placed or disposed of in such a manner or place as to be or to become detrimental to human health or well-being. 
(5)  Sewage, kitchen wastes, laundry wastes or any other wastes deposited upon or allowed to remain upon the ground surface or any other place so as to be or to become detrimental to human health or well-being. 
(6)  The keeping of animals or fowl unless the housing, enclosures or other areas used by the animals or fowl are kept clean, well-drained and free from accumulation of excrement. 
(Code 1976, § 12-2001) 
Sec. 13-52. - Prohibited. 
No person shall create, maintain, support, aid or continue any condition declared to be a nuisance in section 13-51. 
(Code 1976, § 12-2002) 
Secs. 13-53—13-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TOURIST COURTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 91-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 8, 1991, amended Art. IV to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. IV, §§ 13-71—13-80, pertained to tourist courts and trailer parks and derived from Code 1976, §§ 12-3341—12-3350 and Ord. No. 88-18, adopted April 12, 1988. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of Ord. No. 91-01. 
State Law reference— Authority of county board of health to regulate tourist courts, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-5; tourist courts generally, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-1 et seq. 

Sec. 13-71. - Rules and regulations for tourist courts—Adopted. 
All tourist courts shall be in compliance with the April 27, 1984 (revised) rules of the Department of Human Resources, Public Health, Chapter 290-5-18, Tourist Courts, which are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 91-01, § 1, 1-8-91) 
Sec. 13-72. - Same—Exceptions. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the above rules are adopted with the following exceptions: 
(1)  290-5-18-.01 Definitions shall be amended by adding the following: 
(j)  "Approved" means acceptable to the health authority, based on its determination of conformance with this chapter and good public health practices. 
(k)  "Permit" means authorization granted by the health authority to the operator to manage the tourist court and signifies satisfactory compliance with these rules. 
(2)  290-5-18-.02 (1) Provisions shall be amended by adding 
(g)  A permit is the property of the health authority and shall be returned within seven days if the tourist court ceases to operate, is moved, changes location, or if the permit is revoked. 
(3)  290-5-18-.03 Procedures shall be amended by adding to section (2) this sentence: 
The operator shall post the most recent inspection report in public view. 
(4)  290-5-18-.04 Water Supply shall be amended by adding: 
(9)  Existing ice machines shall have tight-fitting doors which are kept closed between service. New or replacement ice machines shall be of the mechanically dispensing type unless ice is dispensed by an employee. 
(10)  Utensils, where furnished, shall be free of chips and cracks, smooth, nonabsorbent, nontoxic, corrosion resistant, and easily cleaned. 
(5)  290-5-18-.05 Toilet Facilities shall be amended by changing the first sentence of section (6) to read: 
Unused, individually wrapped soap or soap dispensed from an approved container shall be provided in guest rooms. 
290-5-18-.05 shall be further amended by striking the last sentence of section (7) and substituting therefor the following: 
An approved method of hand-drying shall be provided in public restrooms. 
(6)  290-5-18-.07 Sewage Disposal shall be amended by striking the entire section and substituting therefor: 
(1)  Tourist courts shall be connected to a public sewer. 
(7)  290-5-18-.09 Refuse Disposal shall be amended by adding to the last sentence of section (3) 
… and in compliance with local, state, and federal regulations. 
(8)  290-5-18-.11 Construction, Layout and Furnishings shall be amended by adding to section (2) the following: 
Where counter top cooking is permitted in guest rooms, an approved ventilation system shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 91-01, § 1, 1-8-91) 
Secs. 13-73—13-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REFUSE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Solid waste, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 13-96. - Definitions.
